commit 5b3a70503c4c9f7f6fdc6635db44582b5a68e657
Author: Jonathan Barnoud <jonathan@barnoud.net>
Date:   2018-12-02 21:13:03 +0100

    Import ABCs from collections.abc (#3171)
    
    * Import ABCs from collections.abc
    
    Importing Abstract Base Classes directly from the collections module is
    deprecated in python 3.8 in favour of the collections.abc module.
    Importing from collections is the only option on python 2.7, though.
    
    This PR tries to import ABCs from collections.abc, and fallback to
    collections in case of failure.
    
    Fixes #3170
    
    * Fix forgotten ABC
    
    * Let go python 2.7 compatibility for ABC imports
    
    Previous changes replaced import of ABCs from collections to imports
    from collections.abc. Though, the changes fell back on bare imports from
    colelctions in python 2.7.
    
    In
    <https://github.com/networkx/networkx/issues/3170#issuecomment-443514900>,
    @dschult comments that the support for python 2.7 is dropped. So this
    commit drops the fall back.

2	1	networkx/algorithms/approximation/kcomponents.py
2	1	networkx/algorithms/lowest_common_ancestors.py
1	1	networkx/classes/coreviews.py
1	1	networkx/classes/graph.py
1	1	networkx/classes/reportviews.py

commit 078e9276ae949d8ed435022c0f2829222274dfed
Author: David Kraeutmann <kane@kane.cx>
Date:   2018-08-07 15:42:13 +0200

    LR planarity checking (#3040)
    
    * LR planarity checking.
    
    Implements a near-linear Left-Right Planarity Test with planar embedding and optional counterexample certificate generation.
    
    Co-authored-by: David Kraeutmann <kane@kane.cx>
    Co-authored-by: Johannes Schulte <johannes.bernhard.schulte@rwth-aachen.de>
    Co-authored-by: Yassin Bahloul <yassin.bahloul@rwth-aachen.de>
    Co-authored-by: Dominik Meier <dominik.meier@rwth-aachen.de>
    
    * Implemented changes according to feedback.
    
    Changes include:
    - Removed recursion of LR-planarity algorithm
    - Added a PlanarEmbedding class
    - Improved Documentation
    - Lower RAM consumption
    
    Co-authored-by: David Kraeutmann <kane@kane.cx>
    Co-authored-by: Johannes Schulte <johannes.bernhard.schulte@rwth-aachen.de>
    Co-authored-by: Yassin Bahloul <yassin.bahloul@rwth-aachen.de>
    Co-authored-by: Dominik Meier <dominik.meier@rwth-aachen.de>

commit e97abea688a471a8422a676ea7c93d079bfa0f1f
Author: Dan Schult <dschult@colgate.edu>
Date:   2018-06-14 13:28:29 -0400

    Remove circular references between graphs and views. (#3011)
    
    Graphs no longer have references to views.
    Views still have references to the graph.
    This should ease subclassing the base graph classes
    because you don't have to worry about creating memory leaks.

commit 5f51a96beb9d1f2e0c95e7796e1467f0bcae656c
Author: Federico Rosato <33623325+f-rosato@users.noreply.github.com>
Date:   2018-02-07 01:14:14 +0100

    Sparse fruchterman needs t scaled by domain size (#2868)
    
    Unlike the regular version of fruchterman reingold, the sparse version doesn't calculate temperature proportionality to domain size. I propose to make the exact same calculation for t in the sparse version, too.
    I noticed this when drawing a graph with a lot of concentrated points with faraway, fixed position (edge length in order of 1-3 and position > 300000, 300000 ) , because a couple of non-fixed nodes refused to get near the others.

1	1	networkx/drawing/layout.py

commit 26f564def49122ab4e72a58a842ae729db68ab7f
Author: Aabir Abubaker Kar <16526730+bakerwho@users.noreply.github.com>
Date:   2018-01-25 11:37:50 -0500

    Fixes local efficiency bug (#2843)
    
    * Fixes issue #2710. Local efficiency should be computed on the subgraph induced by *neighbors* of each node (ref: Latora et al) - however, the node itself should not be included in this computation.
    
    * Fixed tests for efficiency functions.
    
    * Replaced nx.ego_graph() with G.subgraph() and made changes for PEP8
    
    * Changed list comprehension to generator

commit 59d294f7ab3f5e894951c1e1a8a8943acaf6710b
Author: Dan Schult <dschult@colgate.edu>
Date:   2018-01-17 13:48:57 -0500

    Add a large clique size heuristic function (#2830)
    
    * Adds a large clique size heuristic function
    
    This commit creates a new package, `networkx.algorithms.heuristic`, and
    a new module within that package containing a function for finding the
    size of a large clique in a graph.
    
    * Fix typos in docs

commit 6e1d2b3ffa27c47087dbab1baf9225a599966b14
Author: Dan Schult <dschult@colgate.edu>
Date:   2018-01-14 01:25:30 -0500

    Remove automatic processing of G.name attribute (#2829)
    
    It's too hard to keep G.name consistently updated
    throughout the codebase.  Let users do it.
    This stops from deprecating G.name altogether, but
    it is a first step toward that if we decide to go that route.

commit 93b4b9227aa8a7ac4cbd946cf3dae3b168e17b45
Author: Dan Schult <dschult@colgate.edu>
Date:   2018-01-11 08:10:32 -0500

    Add rooted product function (#2825)
    
    Fixes #2062 and thus #2017.
    
    * initial rooted product code
    
    * Adding rooted product code to algorithms.operators.product
    
    Supports the construction of the rooted product of two graphs.
    
    * Accidentally untracked binary.py file adding it back to my branch

commit 29eb74184aea711566fa3a126901d79ea650f1ae
Author: Dima Pasechnik <dimpase@gmail.com>
Date:   2017-12-15 11:22:59 +0000

    use a generic Integral type for parameters check
    
    see https://github.com/networkx/networkx/issues/2799
    By right, the parameters to functions like complete_bipartite() need not be int, as long as they come from a correctly
    defined Integral type. This allows direct usage of Sagemath's Integers, for instance.

commit c60a449f9328cb68fafb456dec7f50275844ce8c
Author: Dan Schult <dschult@colgate.edu>
Date:   2017-12-02 10:03:56 -0500

    Adds prefix_tree, dag_to_branching, and example. (#2784)
    
    This is #2060 with conflicts resolved.  Fixes #2060
    
    This commit adds two new functions and an example application using
    those functions.
    
    - The `prefix_tree` function (in the new module
      `networkx/generators/trees.py`) generates a prefix tree (aka a trie)
      from a given list of strings (or integers, etc.).
    - The `dag_to_branching` function in `networkx/algorithms/dag.py`
      creates the branching that results from interpreting the list of all
      paths from root nodes to leaf nodes in the DAG as the root-to-leaf
      paths in a prefix tree.
    - The example application of the `dag_to_branching` function, in the
      `examples/applications/circuits.py` module, demonstrates how to
      convert a Boolean circuit into an equivalent Boolean formula.

commit a4f4d66a5c0dbd7d7e65def47cea1602d115e6f4
Author: Jordi Torrents <jordi.t21@gmail.com>
Date:   2017-11-27 21:49:11 +0100

    Add flow based node and edge disjoint paths. (#2063)
    
    * Add flow based node and edge dijoint paths.
    
    This is a flow based implementation of edge and node disjoint
    paths. We compute the maximum flow between source and target
    on an auxiliary directed network. This auxiliary network is
    the same used in the flow based edge and node connectivity
    algorithms. See `networkx.algorithms.connectivity.utils`
    for details. The saturated edges in the residual network
    after running the maximum flow algorithm correspond to edge
    or node disjoint paths between source and target in the
    original network.
    
    The user can specify the maximum number of paths to yield,
    but we also take advantatge of the fact the number of disjoint
    paths is bounded by the degree of source and target to speed
    up the computation, especially in sparse graphs.
    
    This function handles both directed and undirected graphs,
    and can use all flow algorithms from NetworkX flow package.
    
    This PR supersedes #2053.
    
    * Fix documentation for disjoint_paths.py

9	0	doc/reference/algorithms/connectivity.rst
2	0	networkx/algorithms/__init__.py
2	0	networkx/algorithms/connectivity/__init__.py
414	0	networkx/algorithms/connectivity/disjoint_paths.py
261	0	networkx/algorithms/connectivity/tests/test_disjoint_paths.py

commit c61824957c948937eede428cd17cf8f8f438a5d8

    [WIP] Graph edit distance 2361 (#2729)

commit 8fb36ea39dbe77f966360384e300fc05e31ddc44
Author: Dan Schult <dschult@colgate.edu>
Date:   2017-11-25 00:30:02 -0500

    Fix bug and add checks for non-convergent fiedler_vector (#2681)
    
    * Fix method choice for alg_conn and fiedler_vector
    
    Still getting random hanging with tracemin_pcg though.
    This is a step toward #2381
    
    * Add check for nonconvergence of pcg method.
    
    Actually checks that 2nd col of W (used to find fiedler vector)
    does not have l_1 norm below 1e-10.
    
    * Rewrite fiedler tracemin_pcg
    
    The Fiedler vector pcg method in rare (but sometimes simple) cases
    projected away too much energy from b in Ax=b so that x was within
    roundoff error and the solver never finished (hung). Despite efforts
    to restore the energy, add noise in orthogonal directions and project
    either more or less often, the system would hang on unlucky initial
    conditions. (Though I did get it to only hang 5 times out of 1 million
    seeds.)
    
    In the end I took a hint from a comment line that the PCG method was
    using a different but mathematically equivalent method to that of
    Cholesky and LU. Rewriting the PCG method to use the same mathematical
    statement as the Chol and LU methods did the trick. Many fewer
    projections might save time, certainly simpler code, and the
    vectors are not close to round-off size. Trials with simple graph
    and initial conditions from seeds 1:1000000 show no signs of hanging.
    
    I believe we can now remove the restriction in the tests that the seed
    be the same each time we test.  Is there a reason to keep the seeds
    the same other than avoiding an infinite loop?
    
    * Move preserve_random_state to utils.py
    
    Remove it from test_algebraic_connectivity.
    It is currently not used anywhere in NetworkX but maybe should be.
    
    * Move numpy import to appropriate place in tests_alg_con

127	106	networkx/linalg/algebraicconnectivity.py
35	46	networkx/linalg/tests/test_algebraic_connectivity.py

commit c3b0761f96cb85d2c4d4b8c7bf6fe451c17fb961
Author: Jack Amadeo <jamadeo@gmail.com>
Date:   2017-10-01 17:54:09 -0400

    Improve subgraph node iteration (#2687)
    
    The show_nodes() filter creates a set from an iterable container.
    However, FilterAtlas will always traverse the entire node set,
    even though the set of nodes is available in this newly constructed
    set.
    
    This change dramatically speeds up node iteration when the subgraph
    is much smaller than the graph.

4	0	networkx/classes/coreviews.py

commit e7b77f0fafe1ce80b92a1f9b828188f248f8647f
Author: Dan Schult <dschult@colgate.edu>
Date:   2017-08-16 00:36:48 -0600

    shortest_path return types as discussed for #2510 (#2612)
    
    * Added all_pairs_dijkstra
    
    * Finds shortest weighted paths and lengths between all nodes.
    * Returns an iterator of dictionaries, keyed by source nodes.
    * Each dictionary essentially contains the value of
      single_source_dijkstra computed at the source node.
      The tuple that single_source_dijkstra returns is unpacked
      and saved as values to two keys: 'distance' and 'path'.
    
    * fixed doctest error
    
    * shortest_path return types as discussed for #2510
    
    This commit only handles the following:
    
    Changed to return a dict:
    - multi_source_dijkstra_path_length
    - single_source_bellman_ford_path_length
    
    Changed to yield 2-tuples:
    - all_pairs_shortest_path
    
    changed to return dicts:
    - single_source_shortest_path_length
    - single_target_shortest_path_length
    
    The following are in #2510:
    Still need these to yield 2-tuples:
    - all_pairs_dijkstra_path
    - all_pairs_bellman_ford_path
    
    Need to add this (and yield 2-tuple):
    - all_pairs_dijkstra
    
    * add/update the all_pairs_dijkstra functions
    
    * fix doctest

    Next attempt to meld graphviews with base classes (#2593)
    
    * Update code to prepare for melding graphviews
    
    * Meld graphviews into graph classes
    
    * Cleanup subgraph calling sign. and remove duplicate code
    
    * Add some tests for raising exceptions
    
    * update edge_kcomponents to avoid readonly views.
    
    * Add root_graph attribute and tests
    
    Update tests for root_graph as well as fresh_copy.
    I left fresh_copy as an attribute even with root_graph
    because a view might switch the data structure of the
    view from directed to undirected. Going to the root_graph.__class__
    may not give you what you need to create a graph like the view.
    Fresh_copy gives a null graph with the directed/multi type of that
    view or graph.

commit 68bf31fee226f75aac85bb395dade7650f2d02db
Author: Dan Schult <dschult@colgate.edu>
Date:   2017-08-09 22:18:25 -0600

    Lowest common ancestor (#2597)
    
    * Added lowest common ancestor for trees.
    
    * Added naive lca algorithm for one-off queries.
    
    * LCA on DAGs apparently working. Still needs tests, docs.
    
    * Performance improvement and docs updates.
    
    * Cleanup, a few things work nicer, and some tests.
    
    * Removed some unnecessary code, improved exception throw order, bug fix.
    
    * Finished tests for the tree LCA.
    
    * Clarified tree error messages and changed how DAG LCA behaves when root is None to be more faithful to the original paper.
    
    * Added main 'does it work' test for the dag algorithm.
    
    * Renamed depths root_distance per Paul Ruŀlan Ferragut's suggestion.
    
    * Improved time and space efficiency when only some pairs are needed.
    
    * Requesting (a, b) and (b, a) from tree lca will now yield both.
    
    * Works for iterators now, albeit kludgily in the case of DAG.
    
    * Removed rooted DAG option as doing it correctly would entail substantial complexity and I can see few use cases for it.
    
    * Multiple roots no longer returning spurious pairs involving the superroot.
    
    * Pair provided to DAG not in graph raises NetworkXError.
    
    * Simplified interface considerably.
    
    * Removed naive algorithm and cleaned up the code a bit.
    
    * Converted to 4 spaces indent, fixed minor style issues and pylint warnings.
    
    * Tree algorithm for LCA does not need to be in nx namespace.
    
    * Improved speed and memory usage in the case where users need a small number of pairs relative to size of the graph.
    
    * Fixed a bug where key errors could come up in first pass when pairs specified.
    
    * Fixed issues from code review.
    
    * Used a slightly better kludge for deciding whether to copy the pairs object if given.
    
    * Fixed not_implemented_for (was AND of conditions but should be OR -- no multigraphs or undirected graphs.)
    
    * Update code to v2.0 interface. clean up docs and pep8

commit 0000bfeec8c5064cd40595e0d6ca784dc345879d
Author: Mohammad Hossein Sekhavat <sekhavat17@gmail.com>
Date:   2017-08-01 02:09:11 +0430

    Graphml: consistent I/O for key and data attributes of edges in multi-graphs (#2559)
    
    * Graphml: read and write key and data attributes of edges in multi-graphs.
    
    Before this commit, key and attribute of multi edges were both stored as `data` xml elements of graphml. This caused difference in edges of multigraphs with key and data attributes after consequent write and reads of graphml. `test_preserve_multi_edge_data` was added to `test_graphml.py` to show this inconsistency.
    This commit changes graphml reader and writer behavior to:
    
    * read and write `key` of networkx edges only in `id` attribute of `<edge id="...">` elements of graphml.
    * read and write `data` of networkx edges only in `<data></data>` elements of graphml.
    
    Only in non-multigraphs, `id` attribute of `<edge id="...">` elements will be read into `data` of networkx edges, because we have no `key` for edges.
    
    * Fix pep8 errors for graphml

24	20	networkx/readwrite/graphml.py
29	0	networkx/readwrite/tests/test_graphml.py

commit f1601955df3e0e9c221cfb0460b761d1d00a2eca
Author: Richard Penney <rwpenney@users.noreply.github.com>
Date:   2017-07-21 21:57:43 +0100

    Kamada-Kawai layout algorithm (#2514)
    
    * Added support for dim>2 in circular_layout().
    
    * Added skeleton of Kamada-Kawai drawing-layout algorithm
    
    Added basic pre-processing for Kamada-Kawai layout function.
    Added cost-function and gradient computation based on preferred separations.
    Added basic 1D test-case for Kamada-Kawai cost-function.
    
    * Wired-up Kamada-Kawai cost-function to scipy.optimize
    
    Added L-BFGS optimization of graph layout using Kamada-Kawai cost-function.
    Improved testing of Kamada-Kawai cost-function in 2D.
    Added parabolic penalty to Kamada-Kawai cost-function.
    
    * Added pylab plotting wrapper for Kamada-Kawai layout.
    
    * Patched unit-tests involving Kamada-Kawai to handle missing SciPy.
    
    * Further tweaks to drawing-layout unit-tests.
    
    Patched sparse Furchterman-Reingold test to use assert_almost_equal().
    Patched slip-up in handling missing scipy for Kamada-Kawai tests.

commit 3457825047df7dd83f266ee54f20d945498999bd
Author: Harry <harryscholes@users.noreply.github.com>
Date:   2017-07-19 14:20:31 +0300

    Add {to, from}_numpy_array functions, resolves #2479 (#2522)
    
    * Add to_numpy_array and from_numpy_array functions
    
    * to_numpy_array returns the graph adjacency matrix as a NumPy array
    
    * from_numpy_array returns a graph from NumPy array
    
    Resolves #2479
    
    * Add tests for to_numpy_array and from_numpy_array
    
    Adapted tests for to_numpy_matrix and from_numpy_matrix. All tests pass on the new array converters.
    
    * Add `to_numpy_array` and `from_numpy_array` functions
    
     - `to_numpy_array` returns the graph adjacency matrix as a NumPy `ndarray`
    
     - `from_numpy_array` returns a graph from a NumPy `ndarray` by calling `from_numpy_matrix`
    
     - `to_numpy_matrix` now calls `to_numpy_array` and converts to a NumPy `matrix`
    
    Resolves #2479

    Allow more flexible multigraph add_edges_from options (#2519)
    
    Can now do (u, v, d) or (u, v, k) with k used only when dict.update(d)
    raises an exception.  Basically if d is a dict or iterator of 2-tuples
    assume it is edge data. Otherwise assume it is a key.

commit ca88758c97a688572cbc70aeffef3d27151acb29
Author: Jordi Torrents <jordi.t21@gmail.com>
Date:   2017-07-09 03:21:13 +0200

     Adds structural hole measures (#2378)
    
    * Adds functions computing structural hole measures
    
    This commit creates a new module, `networkx.algorithms.structuralholes`,
    that provides functions for measuring structural holes in a graph.
    
    * Fix, improve, and speed-up structural holes measures.
    
    This PR supersedes #1535, #429, and #192.
    
    This commit fixes the implementation of constraint and effective size in
    PR #1535. That implementation was using `nx.all_neighbors` to iterate
    over all predecessors and successors of nodes. The problem was that if a
    neighbor is both a predecessor and a successor is appears twice in
    `nx.all_neighbors` and thus it was double counted.
    
    Regarding constraint, PR #1535 was following the formula of constraint
    posted at a very visible web page [1], which is wrong as it says that
    the local constraint has to be calculated only on neighbors that are
    both predecessors and successors of the focal node. Burt's paper [2]
    at page 362 states that "I measure the constraint on each manager with
    respect to the immediate network of discussion partners, composed of
    anyone the manager cited as a discussion partner and anyone who cited
    the manager.", which means that it should be computed for all neighbors
    that are either successors or predecessors.
    
    Regarding effective size, I implemented the original formula proposed by
    Burt in [3], which was different that the one used in #1535. For the
    case of unweighted and undirected graphs I implemented the simplified
    formula proposed by Borgatti [4] which is faster.
    
    After these changes the tests posted in #192 now pass. These test were
    checked using UCINET, I rechecked them using IGraph and also computed them
    by hand to make sure that they were right as I don't have access to
    UCINET and effective size is not implemented in IGraph. I also added more
    tests to cover all cases applicable (weighted, unweighted, directed,
    and undirected).
    
    I changed the API of the functions to compute the measures on all nodes
    of the graph and accept an arbitrary edge weight name to compute the
    weighted versions, following the API of other centrality measures in
    NetworkX.
    
    After profiling these measures, I sped-up the running time by
    reimplementing the inner function `mutual_weight` as a succession of
    `try` and `except` instead of the original generator expression, which
    is ~40% faster. This inner function is called millions of times for not
    so large graphs (thousands of nodes) and thus the speed up is
    significant. On the other hand, I also removed the decorator
    `not_implemented_for` of this function, which according to profiling
    accounted for 50% of the total running time of the measures.
    
    [1] http://www.centiserver.org/?q1=centrality&q2=Burts_constraint
    [2] Burt, R. (2004). "Structural holes and good ideas". American Journal
    of Sociology (110): 349–399.
    [3] Burt, Ronald S. (1995). Structural Holes: The Social Structure of
    Competition. Cambridge: Harvard University Press.
    [4] Borgatti, Stephen (1997). "Structural Holes: Unpacking Burt's
    Redundancy Measures". Connections. INSNA.

1	0	doc/source/reference/algorithms.rst
11	0	doc/source/reference/algorithms.structuralholes.rst
4	2	networkx/algorithms/__init__.py
280	0	networkx/algorithms/structuralholes.py
125	0	networkx/algorithms/tests/test_structuralholes.py

commit e21ae63e85ad3b64cabe551c128e02413441ab70
Author: Dan Schult <dschult@colgate.edu>
Date:   2017-07-03 09:45:15 -0400

    Rebase of Moves is_partition to community.utils (#2496)
    
    * rebase: Moves is_partition to community.utils.
    
    This makes the function `is_partition` public, and ensures that it only
    appears in one place. This commit also changes the `community` package
    so that it behaves like the `bipartite` package, and various others: its
    functions are not exported to the top-level `networkx` namespace; the
    functions must be accessed through `networkx.algorithms.community`.
    
    Finally, this commit also simplifies some of the community tests and
    makes them more readable.
    
    * fix docstring test for Python3.6 Girvan-Newman.
    
    Looks like the top-level communities of a barbell graph differ where
    they put the middle node between python3.6 and python<3.6.
    The next community has three parts without ambiguity so I test that.

commit cb68e1b55c02b81a0166bebea0349efe02a0da85
Author: Richard Penney <rwpenney@users.noreply.github.com>
Date:   2017-07-01 17:57:49 +0100

    Improved vectorization of Fruchterman-Reingold layout. (#2495)
    
    Replaced for-loop over spatial dimensions with pure NumPy indexing.
    Replaced nested array-transpose operations with np.einsum().
    Used numpy.linalg.norm to compute vector lengths.

commit 8fe94545a09f96a15c6cb14d3ca542f82e5457d1
Author: Jarrod Millman <jarrod.millman@gmail.com>
Date:   2017-06-30 09:15:24 -0700

    Fix call to `from_pandas_dataframe` from `to_networkx_graph` (#2490)
    
    * Fix call to `from_pandas_dataframe` from `to_networkx_graph`, fixes #2111
    
    To make this clean, I decided to make `from_pandas_dataframe` only
    require one argument by changing the signature from
    
    ```
    def from_pandas_dataframe(df, source, target, edge_attr=None,
            create_using=None):
    ```
    
    to
    
    ```
    def from_pandas_dataframe(df, source='source', target='target', edge_attr=None,
            create_using=None):
    ```
    
    I added additional tests and expanded a doctest.
    
    * Skip tests if pandas not installed
    
    * Fix docstring for `to_networkx_graph`
    
    * Comply with pep8 and cleanup imports

commit 144f8172770ff7cda91b2aa12eceb672abd5d680
Author: Jordi Torrents <jordi.t21@gmail.com>
Date:   2017-06-28 15:17:47 +0200

    Add Gomory-Hu tree representation of undirected graphs. (#2425)
    
    Thos PR addresses #2421.
    
    A Gomory-Hu tree of an undirected graph with capacities is a
    weighted tree that represents the minimum s-t cuts for all s-t
    pairs in the graph.
    
    It only requires `n-1` minimum cut computations instead of the
    obvious `n(n-1)/2`. The tree represents all s-t cuts as the
    minimum cut value among any pair of nodes is the minimum edge
    weight in the shortest path between the two nodes in the
    Gomory-Hu tree.
    
    The Gomory-Hu tree also has the property that removing the
    edge with the minimum weight in the shortest path between
    any two nodes leaves two connected components that form
    a partition of the nodes in G that defines the minimum s-t
    cut.

8	0	doc/source/reference/algorithms.flow.rst
2	1	networkx/algorithms/__init__.py
1	0	networkx/algorithms/flow/__init__.py
180	0	networkx/algorithms/flow/gomory_hu.py
111	0	networkx/algorithms/flow/tests/test_gomory_hu.py

    Install gdal after creating the conda environment.
    
    This workaround still does not install gdal for python 3.6 but
    it doesn't kill the build, and it works for all other python
    versions. It seems that the probelm is that conda for python 3.6
    installs the latest version of gdal (2.1.3) which is not compatible
    with the package libgdal-dev provided by Travis version of Ubuntu.

commit e8b8a8e7a280a52bece3d64cc09aec87add99b84
Author: Jordi Torrents <jordi.t21@gmail.com>
Date:   2016-11-28 15:49:10 +0100

    Fixes for k-components tests and node connectivity approximation doctests (#5)
    
    * Use octahedral instead of icosahedral for connectivity approx docs.
    
    The approximation algorithm for node connectivity fails on the
    icosahedral graph depending on node iteration order. We use the
    octahedral graph instead as example in the docstrings.
    
    * Fix k-components tests avoiding hard-coded node labels.
    
    In order to support the new dict implementation of python 3.6 we
    have to avoid hard-coding node labels for the k-components of the
    example graphs in k-components tests. We now test the number of
    k-components found, their number of nodes, and their node
    connectivity to make sure that the algorithms are correct.

7	7	networkx/algorithms/approximation/connectivity.py
12	25	networkx/algorithms/approximation/tests/test_kcomponents.py
12	24	networkx/algorithms/connectivity/tests/test_kcomponents.py

    Turns off default doctesting
    
    Doctests are going to be difficult to test because the ordering of the results is dependent on the Python version (different dictionary implementations).

commit 5ded37a124e0bd9111656c22b906a218018ebf69

    Fixes ordering bug in current_flow_betweenness
    
    There was a real ordering bug here that was exposed in Python3.6 testing.
    The simplest fix is to sort order the (integer) nodes to make sure the flow matrix is in the same order as the graph edge data.

commit 24d883489ce92b8a10d816c27ab15806759c8fa1
Author: Aric Hagberg <aric.hagberg@gmail.com>
Date:   2016-11-25 09:27:01 -0700

    Fix test ordering issues for python3.6
    
    The new dictionary implementation in Python3.6 exposes some test issues.  In test where ordering of the dictionaries is assumed the tests may/will fail.  The types of issues most common are
    
    - Nonunique answer (e.g. shortest path on a grid)
    - Need to use assert_edges_equal or assert_nodes_equal to handle ordering differences
    
    - Test isomorphic istead of equal, e.g. we can't guarantee roundrip of networkx->scipy sparse -> networkx with the same labels with our current setup.   In order to do that we'd need to store networkx labels with the scipy sparse data.
    
    Some test items were commented out and need inspection
    
     - non-unique chain test
     - kcomponents test depends on order

5	2	networkx/algorithms/approximation/tests/test_kcomponents.py
3	2	networkx/algorithms/connectivity/tests/test_kcomponents.py

commit 4d721bf8635856901448d8a81ec382ab942cabcc
Author: Jordi Torrents <jordi.t21@gmail.com>
Date:   2017-03-26 14:55:49 +0200

    Improve bipartite documentation.
    
    This PR addresses #2400
    
    Improve bipartite documentation by clarifying that the use of a node
    attribute named `bipartite` with values 0 and 1 in order to
    distinguish bipartite node sets is only a convention which is not
    enforced in the source code. Also state explicitly that bipartite
    functions do not check that the input graph is actually bipartite
    nor than the container with a bipartite node set contains all nodes
    from that bipartite node set.
    
    Added links form all relevant function docstring to the module
    level documentation where all this is explained.
    
    Also added links to some custom exceptions to the generated
    documentation that were missing.

commit 76ce990032825c01bca4fae39db73482c72d7b6e
Author: Jordi Torrents <jordi.t21@gmail.com>
Date:   2017-03-14 16:20:13 +0100

    Check alternating paths using iterative DFS in to_vertex_cover.
    
    This PR fixes #2384.
    
    Reimplement iteratively the inner function `_alternative_dfs` in
    `_is_connected_by_alternating_path`. This function checks if nodes
    in the graph are linked to target nodes by alternating paths, that
    is, paths that alternate between matched and unmatched edges.
    
    This PR also delegates to `_connected_by_alternating_paths`
    computing the matched and unmatched edges because these are the same
    for a given maximum matching and we do not need to recompute them
    each time that we check if a node is linked to targets by an
    alternating path.
    
    I also changed the implementation of the computation of matched and
    unmatched edges in order to avoid assuming orderable nodes.
    
    Added a test with the example given in #2384 and another test with
    unorderable nodes.

42	41	networkx/algorithms/bipartite/matching.py
19	0	networkx/algorithms/bipartite/tests/test_matching.py

commit fc85ed715335bc455708bb04519f508f891c967b

2	2	networkx/algorithms/bipartite/basic.py

commit c8ae2381819e8e922cb0b59026b1e7b5bd26c6c7
Author: Jordi Torrents <jordi.t21@gmail.com>
Date:   2017-03-02 20:25:52 +0100

    Raise an Exception for disconnected Graphs in bipartite.sets
    
    This pull request fixes #2127
    
    When a disconnected graph is passed to `bipartite.sets` more than one
    coloring solution is possible. This led to surprising results and hard
    to diagnose bugs (see #2127) in algorithms that used `bipartite.sets`,
    such as bipartite matching and friends. These algorithms now have a new
    optional parameter that allows the user to specify the nodes in one of
    the two bipartite sets, and thus allows to use disconnected graphs in
    these algorithms without ambiguity.
    
    I've added a new exception `AmbiguousSolution` in order to be more
    explicit when we raise it. It might have more use cases beyond
    `bipartite.sets`.
    
    The changes in this pull request are backwards compatible for connected
    graphs as the new parameter is optional. For disconnected graphs is not
    backward compatible, but since the assignation of nodes to a bipartite
    set depends on iteration order, that code was already subtly broken
    as it would yield different results on different python versions.

3	24	networkx/algorithms/bipartite/__init__.py
37	5	networkx/algorithms/bipartite/basic.py

commit 00525d4dd4724d918fd4c4cc4c883217e758e31e
Author: aryamccarthy <arya.mccarthy@gmail.com>
Date:   2016-12-19 02:14:52 -0600

    Use faster random geometric graph implementation.
    
    Replace the existing random geometric graph generator with one
    that uses a k-d tree to efficiently determine which nodes are
    adjacent, so the algorithm is now `O(n)` instead of `O(n^2)`.
    
    Fall back to non-scipy `O(n^2)` version when scipy is not
    available.
    
    Use p-norm number as parameter instead of function. The
    scipy KDTree requires a number instead of distance function.

4	6	networkx/classes/tests/test_graph.py

commit 5c22e401bdf5fdff19147bd1328a934f8d3205b5
Author: Jeffrey Finkelstein <jeffrey.finkelstein@gmail.com>
Date:   2016-11-02 14:41:03 -0400

    Makes write_graph6 less memory-intensive.
    
    This commit changes the implementation of the `write_graph6` function so
    that it makes better use of iterators and writes directly to file
    instead of buffering the entire encoding of the graph as a string in
    memory before writing. This commit also removes the `generate_graph6`
    function, since it's functionality can be simulated by using the
    `write_graph6` function to write to a file.
    
    This change requires updating the code to explicitly require `bytes`
    when reading and writing graph6 data. This means updating `sparse6` code
    as well.
    
    Finally, this commit standardizes the graph6 and sparse6
    encoding/decoding functions into four functions each: `to_graph6_bytes`,
    `from_graph6_bytes`, `read_graph6`, and `write_graph6`, and the
    corresponding functions for sparse6.

commit 0b0862ebf08c84a9bfe16bf98de67ce044c83bed
Author: aryamccarthy <arya.mccarthy@gmail.com>
Date:   2016-09-29 22:17:14 -0500

    Use faster smallest-last ordering algorithm
    
    Replace the existing implementation of smallest-last ordering with one
    that uses a bucket queue to efficiently determine which node has
    minimum degree, so the algorithm is now `O(m+n)` instead of `O(n^2)`.
    
    Update documentation to credit the Matula and Beck algorithm.
    
    Return a `deque` now, which is okay because the caller requires an
    iterable return value.

commit 1e4fc082f49690c9c04d882454885fd7492897b8
Author: Jeffrey Finkelstein <jeffrey.finkelstein@gmail.com>
Date:   2016-10-07 19:18:09 -0400

    Yield string, not dict, in dfs_labeled_edges.
    
    Previously, the `dfs_labeled_edges` function included yield statements
    of the form
    
        yield u, v, {'dir': 'nontree'}
    
    This commit changes those statements to be
    
        yield u, v, 'nontree'

commit 481f3e8e405cafc05c570e8fc5a2a4d531f86121
Author: leycec <leycec@gmail.com>
Date:   2016-10-03 03:34:24 -0400

    PyDot support reverted from "pydotplus" to "pydot"
    
    Support for the long-obsolete "pydotplus" fork has been reverted back to the
    well-maintained parent "pydot" project, fixing #2235. All "nx_pydot" functions
    now explicitly require pydot >= 1.2.3, which broke backwards API compatibility
    and resolved long-standing Python 2.x issues. Sanity is restored.

commit d50e354bd5cc9ee341e0786e7f79b4d206c6fa1a
Author: Jeffrey Finkelstein <jeffrey.finkelstein@gmail.com>
Date:   2016-09-09 02:15:29 -0400

    Make harmonic centrality more memory-efficient
    
    This commit changes the implementation of harmonic centrality to compute
    single-source shortest path length in the body of a loop instead of
    computing all-pairs shortest path lengths outside of the loop, in order
    to make the implementation more memory efficient.

7	3	networkx/algorithms/centrality/harmonic.py

commit c146c8cb6b39b08f01ea031d8661190acaba2374
Author: James Clough <james.clough91@gmail.com>
Date:   2016-08-03 12:29:12 +0100

    Add transitive_reduction
    
    Add Transitive Reduction as a new feature for Directed Acyclic Graphs.
    This removes all edges which are not necessary to maintain connectivity
    between nodes in the graph.
    This complements the existing transitive_closure function and resolves
    the request in #2185.

    Fix test ordering in readwrite

commit 9a9bab545228359f7e76c42174f14c4a3cc96e2c
Author: Aric Hagberg <aric.hagberg@gmail.com>
Date:   2016-07-31 10:49:36 -0600

    Base class tests
    
    Fix ordering and ambiguity in base class tests.
    The conversion of multidigraphs to multigraphs is ambigious since the ordering can determin the number of resulting edges.  E.g. the multidigraph [(1,2),(2,1),(2,1)] could result in the multigraph [(1,2)] or [(2,1),(2,1)].

    Don't depend on numpy to parse Pajek adjacency matrices.

commit 2435e76b7ed9677dc28e469ae3409cdd5a191846
Author: Jeffrey Finkelstein <jeffrey.finkelstein@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-11-16 01:44:10 -0500

    Adds tree encoding and decoding functions.
    
    This commit makes several additions. The main additions are two
    encoding/decoding schemes for trees, the nested tuple and Prüfer
    sequence schemes. These appear in a new module,
    `networkx.algorithms.tree.coding`.
    
    These encoding/decoding functions required implementing a function for
    joining subtrees at a root node, which appears as the `join` function in
    a new module, `networkx.algorithms.tree.operations`.
    
    Finally, the encoding/decoding schemes suggest a simple implementation
    for generating a uniformly random tree. The random tree generator first
    generates a random Prüfer sequence, then converts that sequence to the
    corresponding tree. This `random_tree` function appears in a new module,
    `networkx.generators.tree`.

27	0	doc/source/reference/algorithms.tree.rst
9	0	doc/source/reference/generators.rst
3	1	networkx/algorithms/__init__.py

commit a831a0ec013adc075a4cbdca2b8ad4b5b8f0c9c3
Author: Jordi Torrents <jordi.t21@gmail.com>
Date:   2016-07-23 11:54:18 +0200

    Refactor Dinitz' algorithm implementation.
    
    Reimplemented the DFS iteratively instead of recursively. This
    speeds up the running time considerably, specially for problems
    in which the paths between source and sink are long, such as big
    and sparse networks (eg social networks). For dense networks, in
    which the paths are typically short, the running time is very
    simmilar to the recursive implementation.
    
    The speed up in the running time makes now possible to use Dinitz'
    algorithm for testing the large graphs in `test_maxflow_large_graph.py`.
    Thus we are now using all flow algorithms in all flow tests.

38	33	networkx/algorithms/flow/dinitz_alg.py
8	4	networkx/algorithms/flow/tests/test_maxflow_large_graph.py

Author: Jeffrey Finkelstein <jeffrey.finkelstein@gmail.com>
Date:   2016-04-06 01:57:07 -0400

    Moves Graph Atlas to data file.
    
    This commit moves the edge lists of the graphs in the graph atlas from a
    Python list defined in `networkx/generators/atlas.py` to a text file in
    the same directory. This means that accessing the list of atlas graphs
    will cause a file read.
    
    This also adds a new function, `graph_atlas(i)`, that outputs only the
    `i`th graph from the atlas.

commit abd125cc18e764a4df62d47f982972240dee811c
Author: Jeffrey Finkelstein <jeffrey.finkelstein@gmail.com>
Date:   2016-05-25 12:46:58 -0400

    Adds exception: failed power iteration convergence
    
    This commit adds two new exceptions, `ExceededMaxIterations` and its
    subclass `PowerIterationFailedConvergence`, intended to be used by
    algorithms that accept a `max_iter` keyword argument specifying the
    maximum number of allowable iterations of a main loop. Several existing
    algorithms have been modified to raise these more meaningful exceptions.

commit 1b85abab0ef52f7c086a721f157997a23331a5b4
Author: Jeffrey Finkelstein <jeffrey.finkelstein@gmail.com>
Date:   2016-05-16 03:13:09 -0400

    Adds beam search traversal algorithm with example
    
    This commit adds the generalization of breadth-first search known as
    "beam search", in which only a subset of "good" neighbors are enqueued
    when visiting a new node. This refactors the breadth-first search
    functions to call a generic BFS helper function that allows an arbitrary
    successors function.
    
    This also adds an example application, which is the progressive widening
    beam search.

9	0	doc/source/reference/algorithms.traversal.rst
100	0	examples/algorithms/beam_search.py
2	1	networkx/algorithms/traversal/__init__.py
105	0	networkx/algorithms/traversal/beamsearch.py
82	23	networkx/algorithms/traversal/breadth_first_search.py
38	0	networkx/algorithms/traversal/tests/test_beamsearch.py

commit 000be6756cdaf9d9c96391e5b7b4c8b0c3674484
Author: Jordi Torrents <jordi.t21@gmail.com>
Date:   2016-05-11 22:46:11 +0200

    Add search trees to a graph attribute and improve documentation.
    
    A nice feature of the Boykov-Kolmogorov algorithm is that a partition
    of the nodes that defines a minimum cut can be easily computed based
    on the search trees used during the algorithm. These trees are now
    stored in the graph attribute `trees` of the residual network.
    
    Also added an example in the docstrings on how to compute the
    partition that defines a minimum cut from the source and target
    search trees, along with a refernece to the marking heuristic,
    which is what makes this algorithm fast in practice for many
    problems.

28	2	networkx/algorithms/flow/boykovkolmogorov.py

commit 78d8a476161f9ff426eabf9c011e5985ad3b54e7
Author: Jordi Torrents <jordi.t21@gmail.com>
Date:   2016-05-11 19:30:34 +0200

    Do not use lambda for the key argument for sorting.
    
    Adding distance estimate to the generator and then using
    itemgetter for the sorted function is faster than using
    lambda.

7	4	networkx/algorithms/flow/boykovkolmogorov.py

commit e5689a8e50d020d1316d812beee8b1bdefe4b2ad
Author: Jordi Torrents <jordi.t21@gmail.com>
Date:   2016-05-09 23:34:28 +0200

    Implement marking heuristic for Boykov-Kolmogorov algorithm.
    
    This heuristic uses an estimate of the distance to the root for
    every node in both search trees, and a timestamp reflecting
    when the distance was computed. As time goes by this estimate
    gets outdated. In the adoption stage it is necessary to routinely
    do checks in the search trees to see if a given node has source
    or target as a root of its tree (see `_has_valid_root`), when
    this checks are performed the distance estimate for each node
    is updated. See [1] (pp. 109-114) for further details.
    
    The aim of this heuristic is to shorten the paths that are
    discovered in the growth stage, because after the first one,
    there is no guarantee that other discovered paths will be the
    short. In the adoption stage the search trees can be modified
    in strange ways without applying this heuristic.
    
    As a result the running time in many practical problems is
    greatly improved.
    
    [1] Vladimir Kolmogorov. Graph-based Algorithms for Multi-camera
    Reconstruction Problem. PhD thesis, Cornell University, CS Department,
    2003.
    https://pub.ist.ac.at/~vnk/papers/thesis.pdf

74	31	networkx/algorithms/flow/boykovkolmogorov.py

commit bb5fb2ed0b3df59488b2a65a21ebf31c009cb450
Author: Jordi Torrents <jordi.t21@gmail.com>
Date:   2016-05-06 03:43:33 +0200

    Add Boykov Kolmogorov algorithm for maximum flow problems.
    
    This algorithm has worse case complexity `O(n^2m|C|)` where |C| is the
    cost of the minimum cut [1], but it is faster than other algorithms with
    theoretically better worse case complexities for some problems, such as
    vision and image processing, and maybe others.
    
    For the case of connectivity problems in networks with higly skewed
    degree distributions (eg social networks) this algorithm doesn't run
    faster than Edmonds-Karp but after reading about it I thought that it
    was really cool and decided to implement it.
    
    This is still WIP as the marking heuristic described in [2] is
    not yet implemented. According to the authors it speeds up the running
    time considerably.
    
    [1] Boykov, Y., & Kolmogorov, V. (2004). An experimental comparison of
    min-cut/max-flow algorithms for energy minimization in vision.
    http://www.csd.uwo.ca/~yuri/Papers/pami04.pdf
    [2] Vladimir Kolmogorov. Graph-based Algorithms for Multi-camera
    Reconstruction Problem. PhD thesis, Cornell University, CS Department,
    2003. pp. 109-114.
    https://pub.ist.ac.at/~vnk/papers/thesis.pdf

8	0	doc/source/reference/algorithms.flow.rst

    case).

    The same mutation (attr_dict mutations) that occurred in add_node

    test failure (passing an empty sequence shouldn't really raise an error,
    since you can update a dictionary with an empty sequence without raising
    an error).

commit 57ae653154cb5701d443935a0bbca10b9c649875
Author: thegreathippo <thegreathippo@gmail.com>
Date:   2016-04-25 19:00:18 -0400

    Modified Graph.add_node and test_add_node.
    
    Graph.add_node mutated the attr_dict parameter and assigned it directly
    to the graph's node dictionary, creating potential for unexpected
    behavior. Creating a new dictionary based on the supplied attr_dict (and
    updated with the supplied kwargs) avoids this problem -- also had to
    update the test for adding nodes, since sending an empty sequence no
    longer raises an error (which seems reasonable).

23	9	networkx/classes/graph.py
1	1	networkx/classes/tests/test_graph.py

commit fe3c5073b9f68b9afd366ed8e91c21abafcb3a7c
Author: Jordi Torrents <jordi.t21@gmail.com>
Date:   2016-04-24 22:19:27 +0200

commit 08fc802e1fd648700767638fcd6615c09e0294ff
Author: Jordi Torrents <jordi.t21@gmail.com>
Date:   2016-04-24 21:07:56 +0200

    Speed up the implementation.
    
    Three main changes: 1) check for unboundedness outside DFS, 2) stop
    BFS as soon as we find target, and 3) add R_succ to the local namespace
    and use it instead of R.succ.

commit 15c689f04b5cbd0f4fc2facdf23240ce4fff4098
Author: Jordi Torrents <jordi.t21@gmail.com>
Date:   2016-04-24 19:41:32 +0200

    Add Dinitz algorithm to connectivity tests.
    
    Also applied cutoff for Dinitz when computing edge and
    node connectivity. This has to be done for each new algorithm
    that supports cutoff because cutoff is not a parameter that all
    flow algorithms must support in the NetworkX flow API.

Date:   2016-02-23 07:31:27 -0500

    Handles length zero or one lists in is_simple_path
    
    This commit adds some cases to `is_simple_path`. A list of length zero
    is not a valid path, while a list of length one is a valid path, as long
    as the sole element of the list is in the graph.

    Abstracts many-to-one grouping function.
    
    This commit adds the utility function `groups()`, which, given a
    dictionary representing a many-to-one mapping, outputs the "inverse"
    one-to-many mapping, which maps values to the set of keys that have that
    value.

commit fca8c0b1049507d751398e527d8c55fb3d8b13b1
Author: Jeffrey Finkelstein <jeffrey.finkelstein@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-08-04 00:35:23 -0400

    Makes girvan_newman return communities as sets.
    
    Previously, the community-finding algorithm `girvan_newman` returned a
    list of tuples of lists of nodes. Now the function returns an iterator
    over tuples of sets of nodes, each set representing a community. This
    matches the behavior of the other community-finding functions.
    
    This also prevents computing the connected components of the graph an
    additional time when yielding the tuples of communities.

74	32	networkx/algorithms/community/centrality.py
6	6	networkx/algorithms/community/tests/test_centrality.py

commit af8a2d82088be7dd7b69bf96d0d39254f145bbde
Author: Jeffrey Finkelstein <jeffrey.finkelstein@gmail.com>
Date:   2016-03-21 01:58:15 -0400

    Support digraphs in approximate min vertex cover
    
    This commit removes the decorator that marked the approximate minimum
    weighted vertex cover function as "not implemented" for directed graphs,
    because it works for a reasonable definition of vertex cover in directed
    graphs.
    
    This also updates the documentation and tests.

34	16	networkx/algorithms/approximation/tests/test_vertex_cover.py
55	38	networkx/algorithms/approximation/vertex_cover.py

commit a772267173f1e2f9e413b6a3be59bb81e2e16ba1
Author: Jeffrey Finkelstein <jeffrey.finkelstein@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-07-29 17:55:49 -0400

    Allows arbitrary metric in geometric generators.
    
    This commit adds the `metric` keyword argument to three functions in
    `networkx.generators.geometric`, namely
    
    * `random_geometric_graph`,
    * `waxman_graph`,
    * `geographical_threshold_graph'.
    
    This keyword argument allows the function to compare distances between
    nodes according to arbitrary metric functions instead of hardcoded
    Euclidean metrics. The default behavior if no `metric` argument is
    specified remains the Euclidean metric.
    
    This commit also cleans and simplifies the implementations of these
    three functions, as well as adds more meaningful unit tests.

214	123	networkx/generators/geometric.py
145	24	networkx/generators/tests/test_geometric.py

commit 9f116814bd74d6eb228a109490914695729c2959
Author: Alex Ryan <ialexryan@users.noreply.github.com>
Date:   2016-02-25 17:27:36 -0800

    Fix MultiDiGraph() docstring to reflect input flexibility
    
    The existing documentation on the MultiDiGraph() constructor function says that it can only take "an edge list or a NetworkX graph object" as well as a few third-party formats. This isn't true, since the data is just passed to the to_networkx_graph() function, which can actually accept a far wider variety of input formats - including dict of dicts and dict of lists.

5	5	networkx/classes/multidigraph.py

commit 0d636d2c9fd0a45b9207ca3bc28af40622357753
Author: Jeffrey Finkelstein <jeffrey.finkelstein@gmail.com>
Date:   2016-01-08 16:10:43 -0500

    Fixes tests for maximal matching.
    
    Previously the tests for maximal matchings were testing that a given set
    of edges was an edge cover, *not* a matching. In addition, they were not
    testing maximality of the matching. This updates the tests to correctly
    test that the `maximal_matching()` function returns a valid maximal
    matching.
    
    As part of this fix, this commit also introduces two public functions,
    `is_matching()` and `is_maximal_matching()`, which decide whether a
    given set of edges is a valid matching or maximal matching,
    respectively.

114	19	networkx/algorithms/matching.py
107	74	networkx/algorithms/tests/test_matching.py

commit 1f27e84f8e9667074bad1020c096ceacd1b81ed7
Author: Jordi Torrents <jordi.t21@gmail.com>
Date:   2016-02-05 20:33:31 +0100

    A left over in the docstring from the last refactor made somewhat
    not clear that the functions in cuts.py do not consider weights
    and compute cuts in terms only of number of nodes or edges. Also
    added a reference to `minimum_cut` for the users interested in
    weighted edge cuts.

2	4	networkx/algorithms/connectivity/cuts.py

commit 9932e18bf371e76c49643f62681fdb0b3fadd2cb
Author: Jordi Torrents <jordi.t21@gmail.com>
Date:   2016-02-05 19:17:21 +0100

    Fix all_node_cuts corner cases: cycle and complete graphs.
    
    This PR fixes #1875 . For cycle graphs and complete graphs all_node_cuts
    was giving incorrect or incomplete results. The most tricky case is cycle
    graphs because handling them as a part of the implementation of Kanevsky's
    algorithm requires checks inside tight loops that would penalize the common
    case.
    
    Instead in this PR cycle and complete graphs are handled separately. It is
    cheap to test if the input graph is any of both, and the solution of finding
    all node cuts is a lot easier and faster than in the general case.
    
    Also added tests for both cycle and complete graphs.

17	0	networkx/algorithms/connectivity/kcutsets.py
24	0	networkx/algorithms/connectivity/tests/test_kcutsets.py

commit e554cda5d354929613c215f68299a0b227af6604
Author: Jordi Torrents <jordi.t21@gmail.com>
Date:   2016-02-04 22:09:15 +0100

    Add Dinitz' algorithm for maximum flow problems.
    
    This implmentation is based on Cherkassky's approach (see section 4 of
    this very nice paper [1]). That is, do not explicitly construct the layered
    network, just compute the layer number or rank of each node in the BFS tree
    up to distance = dist(s, t). Then in the DFS, just ignore both edges between
    nodes of incompatibe ranks and saturated edges.
    
    I've implemented this algorithm with hopes of speed up flow based connectivity
    algorithms. Turns out that Edmonds Karp algorithm clearly outperforms this one.
    Although this one outperforms clearly Preflow-push and Short-augmenting-paths
    for very sparse networks with skewed degree distributions. The paper suggest
    other improvements not implemented here.
    
    [1] Dinitz' Algorithm: The Original Version and Even's Version.
        http://www.cs.bgu.ac.il/~dinitz/Papers/Dinitz_alg.pdf

1	0	networkx/algorithms/flow/__init__.py

commit d78c1d08cee6b17b9eaecb00526af2849c2b34c9
Author: Dan Schult <dschult@colgate.edu>
Date:   2016-01-06 19:58:37 -0500

    Overload graph generators to allow nodes or number
    
    Create decorator @nodes_or_number(which_args) which
    replaces the arguments given in which_args with a
    2-tuple (n_name, nodes) where n_name is the original
    argument value and nodes is the resulting list of nodes.
    
    Implemented for:
    
       empty_graph
       path_graph
       cycle_graph
       star_graph
       wheel_graph
       grid_2d_graph
       lollipop_graph
       complete_graph
       complete_bipartite_graph
       complete_multipartite_graph
       grid_grap
       random_geometric_grap
       geographical_threshold_grap
       waxman_grap

46	41	networkx/algorithms/bipartite/generators.py

commit 98e84343c2bd10862014e73c3a7208f7f06475f0
Author: Jeffrey Finkelstein <jeffrey.finkelstein@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-12-17 10:30:12 -0500

    Allows copying a graph without attribute data.
    
    Adds the `with_data` keyword argument to the `Graph.copy()` method,
    which specifies whether the graph, node, and edge data will be included
    in the copy of the graph object.
    
    This commit also updates algorithms that include a call to
    `Graph.copy()` to use `with_data=False` if they really do not need a
    copy of the data.

Date:   2015-06-10 01:09:52 -0400

    Find max clique and independent set by cardinality
    
    Before, the maximum clique and maximum independent set were chosen from
    a collection of candidates according to the subset ordering on
    sets. This commit changes the code to choose the maximum clique and
    maximum independent set according to cardinality of the sets.

commit 8b6ea313675cd98a0b0b1129e3891c8cb344c31a
Author: Jeffrey Finkelstein <jeffrey.finkelstein@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-06-12 14:23:05 -0400

    Fixes and extends Wiener index, vitality functions
    
    Previously, the closeness vitality function was using an incorrect
    definition of the Wiener index, counting each orientation of a pair of
    nodes in an undirected graph twice. This commit corrects the behavior of
    the Wiener index function and therefore the closeness vitality function.
    
    Correcting the Wiener index function also corrects another case for the
    closeness vitality function: when removing a node causes a graph to
    become disconnected. By definition, the closeness vitality of a node
    whose removal causes the graph to become disconnected should be negative
    infinity. This commit fixes the Wiener index function to return positive
    infinity on a disconnected graph.
    
    Furthermore, this commit improves the closeness vitality function so
    that it does not mutate the graph in order to compute the vitality
    value.
    
    Finally, this places the Wiener index function in its own module,
    documents it, and makes it available to the end user.

9	0	doc/source/reference/algorithms.wiener.rst
1	0	networkx/algorithms/__init__.py
41	33	networkx/algorithms/tests/test_vitality.py
80	0	networkx/algorithms/tests/test_wiener.py
43	54	networkx/algorithms/vitality.py
86	0	networkx/algorithms/wiener.py

    Adds functions for measuring cuts.

    volume, and expansion, among others. In doing so, this commit also
    updates `networkx.algorithms.boundary` to accommodate multigraphs and
    directed graphs.

commit 4801161602d27c81f640ec057b15e41c4fcc330e
Author: Jeffrey Finkelstein <jeffrey.finkelstein@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-07-20 21:50:08 -0400

    Cleans make_max_clique_graph, make_clique_bipartite
    
    This commit makes several updates to networkx/algorithms/clique.py,
    including
    
    - removing some unnecessary arguments to the functions,
    - updates documentation strings,
    - removes the local `project_up` and `project_down` functions, which
      were duplicating the bipartite projection functions
    - sets the node attributes of the bipartite clique graph in the same way
      as the bipartite generator functions (that is, setting the `bipartite`
      node attribute to be 0 for the "top" nodes and 1 for the "bottom"
      nodes).
    
    Since the signature of these functions has changed, this is not a
    backwards-compatible change.

commit 85d3e4265fefc18bf77f8e2a58ced81325d17890
Author: Antoine Mazières <antoine.mazieres@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-10-27 21:47:17 +0100

    Fix, now raise NetworkXError instead of TypeError
    
    Instead of :
    
    ```
    'dict' objects are unhashableTraceback (most recent call last):
      File "<builtin>/app_main.py", line 75, in run_toplevel
      File "mk_graph_file.py", line 34, in <module>
        if d['weight'] > 3])
      File "/usr/local/lib/pypy2.7/dist-packages/networkx/classes/graph.py", line 1488, in subgraph
        for n in bunch:
      File "/usr/local/lib/pypy2.7/dist-packages/networkx/classes/graph.py", line 1815, in bunch_iter
        "Node %s in the sequence nbunch is not a valid node."%n)
    TypeError: not all arguments converted during string formatting
    ```
    
    You get:
    
    ```
    'dict' objects are unhashableTraceback (most recent call last):
      File "<builtin>/app_main.py", line 75, in run_toplevel
      File "mk_graph_file.py", line 34, in <module>
        if d['weight'] > 3])
      File "/usr/local/lib/pypy2.7/dist-packages/networkx/classes/graph.py", line 1488, in subgraph
        for n in bunch:
      File "/usr/local/lib/pypy2.7/dist-packages/networkx/classes/graph.py", line 1815, in bunch_iter
        "Node {} in the sequence nbunch is not a valid node.".format(n))
    NetworkXError: Node ('java', 'performance', {'weight': 5}) in the sequence nbunch is not a valid node.
    ```

commit 4cd32dd0780e0e1147d347a5a0c47532c29ac976
Author: Jeffrey Finkelstein <jeffrey.finkelstein@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-09-16 20:40:33 -0400

    Makes balanced unary tree generator return path.
    
    Previously, the `balanced_tree` generator function always returned a
    path graph on two nodes instead of a path graph of the appropriate
    length when provided a branching factor of one. This corrects that error
    so the function now returns the path graph on `h + 1` nodes, where `h`
    is the specified height of the tree, when the branching factor is one.

41	28	networkx/generators/classic.py
10	0	networkx/generators/tests/test_classic.py

commit 12826ab07b15e92241cda4d870b16777b31bed8a
Author: Jeffrey Finkelstein <jeffrey.finkelstein@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-06-10 02:38:50 -0400

    Rewrites quotient so it can implement block model
    
    This commit removes the `blockmodel()` function (and its containing
    module `networkx.algorithms.block`) and adds code to the
    `quotient_graph()` function so that it can handle the use cases for
    `blockmodel()`.
    
    This is a backwards-incompatible change; it removes a function.

0	9	doc/source/reference/algorithms.block.rst

commit 943c96f9c510b1b4cfb71007723c50bba21d0e84
Author: Jeffrey Finkelstein <jeffrey.finkelstein@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-08-28 22:24:04 -0400

    Moves triad_graph function to generators package.
    
    Previously, the `triad_graphs` function in the
    `networkx.algorithms.triads` module, returned a dictionary containing a
    graph representing each possible triad. This commit moves that function
    to a new module, `networkx.generators.triads`, and adds previously
    missing test code for that function. It also modifies the function to
    return a single graph instead of a dictionary of graphs. The dictionary
    can now be generated by the code
    
        from networkx.algorithms.triads import TRIAD_NAMES
        triad_graphs = {name: triad_graph(name) for name in TRIAD_NAMES}

9	0	doc/source/reference/generators.rst
12	42	networkx/algorithms/triads.py
6	5	networkx/generators/__init__.py
21	0	networkx/generators/tests/test_triads.py

commit 45667709f0a267786dab6c2095c4a28d3297a70b
Author: Neil <mistersheik@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-07-13 15:24:07 -0400

    topolgical_sort, lexicographical_topological_sort
    
    Rewrote topolgical_sort as a generator:
    * It no longer accepts reverse or nbunch arguments
    * It is slightly faster.
    Added lexicographical_topological_sort, which accepts a key.
    Some tests for topological sort were removed because they relied on
    CPython's particular dict element ordering.
    Added utils from more_itertools:
    * These were necessary for working with the new generators.
    * "pairwise" is equavalent to zip(some_list, some_list[1:]) -- for
    generators.
    * "consume" consumes an iterator.

2	3	networkx/algorithms/dag.py

    Fix type inference to be python3 compatible
    
    Due to issues with long not existing in python 3, we need to reassign it
    in the case of python 3 to int.
    
    In addition we have to pull in lxml in order to parse the generated XML
    to ensure it has the proper number of keys. We cannot compare to the
    fixture due to mixed results in the ordering between python versions.

commit 46cd031121a2803debb1bf8e2f1ffa35fbe9ee47
Author: Dan Schult <dschult@colgate.edu>
Date:   2015-08-10 13:30:42 -0400

    Eigenvector_centrality power method shifted to A+I
    
    By computing eigenvectors with repeated multiplication by A+I
    the spectrum is shifted so that the positive real eigenvalue
    is dominant even for odd path graphs and others with multiple
    dominant eigenvalues.

10	7	networkx/algorithms/centrality/eigenvector.py

commit ec154654a206502593bebe5bd9e02183e6a287c7
Merge: 7a16ccec 087c719e
Author: jfinkels <jfinkels@users.noreply.github.com>

commit 087c719eda2da21357c3cfd01252b1e8c130329b
Author: Thodoris Sotiropoulos <theosotr@windowslive.com>
Date:   2015-04-15 21:44:13 +0300

    Add Girvan-Newman algorithm
    
    The Girvan–Newman algorithm detects communities by progressively
    removing edges from the original graph. Algorithm removes edge with the
    highest betweenness centrality at each step. As the graph breaks down
    into pieces, the tightly knit community structure is exposed and result
    can be depicted as a dendogram.
    
    For this reason new module centrality.py was created

8	0	doc/source/reference/algorithms.community.rst
2	1	networkx/algorithms/community/__init__.py
64	0	networkx/algorithms/community/centrality.py
79	0	networkx/algorithms/community/tests/test_centrality.py

commit 2f70ad71c5c9bf5e1929f78fc5f0d25c397a7652
Author: Jeffrey Finkelstein <jeffrey.finkelstein@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-05-19 21:50:48 -0400

    Use peek(S) instead of next(iter(S)).
    
    As of the date of this commit, there is no way to get an arbitrary
    element of an iterable like a set without modifying it (for example, as
    in `set.pop()`). The `peek()` function is more readable than writing
    
        next(iter(S))
    
    whenever an arbitrary element of an iterable is required.

commit 8db15d970ac37453a876cd28f09d2d1bea742651
Author: Jordi Torrents <jordi.t21@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-07-13 12:47:24 +0200

    Remove some tests for k_components approximation.
    
    This algorithm is based on a node connectivity approximation that only
    guarantees a lower bound for node connectivity. Even though some tests only
    fail sporadically in Travis, and we cannot reproduce them, it's better to just
    remove the problematic tests based on random graphs. Those tests were designed
    for the exact implementation of the algorithm in `connectivity/kcomponents.py`.

    exists.

commit d49733b61fb7dedfbbbdd9c04464adf6beb5db07
Merge: 00afd39d 13884373
Author: chebee7i <chebee7i@gmail.com>

commit 138843738dc2e9ce931b9ec86ac0443e46e6e4da
Author: Jeffrey Finkelstein <jeffrey.finkelstein@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-06-06 00:34:41 -0400

    Fixes approximate dominating set greedy choice.
    
    Before, the greedy algorithm for approximate dominating set chose each
    node based on the sum of the weights in the closed neighborhood of the
    node. Now it just uses the weight of the node. This fixes an issue that
    causes, for example, the return value for a star graph to be all nodes
    other than the center node.

commit aa665f29dd38b728c864134dc8b87ffe7135e983
Author: Jordi Torrents <jordi.t21@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-03-18 13:39:42 +0100

    Add fast approximation for k-(node)-components.
    
    This is an approximation approach to compute the k-component structure
    of a graph (#1414 is the exact, and slow, version of this). I wrote a
    paper to explore this approach in detail, see http://arxiv.org/abs/1503.04476
    
    The logic of the approximation algorithm for computing the `k`-component
    structure is based on repeatedly applying simple and fast algorithms
    for `k`-cores and biconnected components in order to narrow down the
    number of pairs of nodes over which we have to compute White and Newman's
    approximation algorithm for finding node independent paths (implemented at #1405).
    More formally, this algorithm is based on Whitney's theorem, which states
    an inclusion relation among node connectivity, edge connectivity, and
    minimum degree for any graph G. This theorem implies that every
    `k`-component is nested inside a `k`-edge-component, which in turn,
    is contained in a `k`-core. Thus, this algorithm computes node independent
    paths among pairs of nodes in each biconnected part of each `k`-core,
    and repeats this procedure for each `k` from 3 to the maximal core number
    of a node in the input graph.
    
    Because, in practice, many nodes of the core of level `k` inside a
    bicomponent actually are part of a component of level k, the auxiliary
    graph needed for the algorithm it's likely to be very dense. Thus, we use
    a complement graph data structure to save memory (`_AntiGraph` see #599
    for an earlier dicussion about this). AntiGraph only stores information
    of the edges that are *not* present in the actual auxiliary graph.
    However, when applying algorithms to this complement graph data structure,
    it behaves as if it were the dense version. So it can be used directly
    in several NetworkX algorithms, this version is only tested for the
    algorithms needed here: `connected_components`, `k-cores`, and
    `biconnected_components`. I used a `ThinGraph` for building the `AntiGraph`
    and the memory consumption is quite small compared with a regular `Graph`.
    
    I think `AntiGraph` is not useful enough to be a top level class in NetworkX,
    but it could be a good example of a `Graph` subclass. I'll add to the
    examples folder.
    
    This PR supersedes and closes #580.

1	0	networkx/algorithms/approximation/__init__.py
366	0	networkx/algorithms/approximation/kcomponents.py
327	0	networkx/algorithms/approximation/tests/test_kcomponents.py

commit 6a65210247d5e65e17e134d5234207d36d9c006a

commit ab6c4c429452ac48f58f7106db3efa7d79358a51
Author: Jordi Torrents <jordi.t21@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-03-17 21:48:31 +0100

    Add k-(node)-components algorithm.
    
    Add Moody and White algorithm for for identifying k-components in a graph,
    which is based on Kanevsky's algorithm for finding all minimum-size node
    cut-sets (implemented in `all_node_cuts` function #1391). This algorithm
    consists in keep cutting a graph until we obtain either a complete or a
    trivial graph.
    
    `all_node_cuts` is doing most of the work here, the only tricky
    implementation thing is the generation of partitions. The authors say that
    ``Nodes in a cutset belong to both sides of the induced cut.'', but an
    induced cut can split a graph in more than two sides. Thus, after a cut,
    we have to merge the node sets that (after adding the nodes in the cut set)
    share at least k nodes.
    
    I found out that this is very related to set consolidation, which is
    implemented using connected components. This implementation is slower
    than the iterative version from rosettacode.org because of the overhead
    of building a graph and calling nx.connected_components, but we perform
    the same number of intersection operations.
    
    Also, it's possible that subsets of an already detected k-component appear
    at a level k. Checking for this in the main while loop penalizes the common
    case. Thus we also have to _consolidate all connectivity levels in
    _reconstruct_k_components.

commit d72b854ef6ad39cd346498752da19cfeff41192f
Author: Jordi Torrents <jordi.t21@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-05-03 17:13:27 +0200

    Refactor and improve the documentation for connected_components.
    
    Make connected_components a generator of sets of nodes, it was a generator
    of list of nodes. See #1501 for discussion.
    
    Use a plain BFS to compute them instead of using the single source
    shortest path function. The latter also does a BFS but keeps track of the
    distances. This is only slightly faster for small graphs (arround 5% in my
    tests), but for larger graphs the speed up is more relevant (around 1.8x
    faster). Also I think it's conceptually better. As @ysitu said, we have a
    tendency to abuse shortest paths functions for reachability.
    
    Also improved biconnected components examples, docstrings, and code.

8	0	doc/source/reference/api_2.0.rst
94	38	networkx/algorithms/components/biconnected.py
54	17	networkx/algorithms/components/connected.py

commit 3a7ae8ebcbfc52a111dddaf5d131547421f98070

commit 5c68570a58d623d8b8134621766909a5f3cf7086
Author: Jeffrey Finkelstein <jeffrey.finkelstein@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-04-22 23:04:05 -0400

    Optimization for connected double edge swap.
    
    This implements an optimization that speeds up the
    `connected_double_edge_swap()` function. It uses a threshold, below
    which graph connectivity is checked after each swap, and above which,
    graph connectivity is only checked after a number of swaps are made.

140	54	networkx/algorithms/swap.py

commit dc473c7364ca9ca20e11c26d486d960d55f78c85
Merge: 2d2f5c7a 8a35d56c
Author: chebee7i <chebee7i@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-04-18 18:03:58 -0500

    Merge pull request #1463 from jfinkels/accumulate
    
    Replaces cumulative_sum with accumulate.

commit 8a35d56c530da52939f9aa34d604f9cd05afecb0
Author: Jeffrey Finkelstein <jeffrey.finkelstein@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-04-18 12:12:34 -0400

    Replaces cumulative_sum with accumulate.
    
    Python 3.2 introduces the `itertools.accumulate()`. Before, we were
    using less flexible custom code for performing the same task, in
    `networkx.utils.misc.cumulative_sum`. This commit replaces calls to
    `cumulative_sum` with calls to `itertools.accumulate()`.
    
    Since we currently still support Python 2.7, this commit adds a fallback
    equivalent definition of accumulate that matches the Python 3.2
    implementation. Once support for Python 2.7 is dropped, all of this code
    can be removed, and calls to `networkx.utils.accumulate()` can be
    replaced by calls to `itertools.accumulate()`.

1	1	networkx/algorithms/richclub.py
1	1	networkx/generators/geometric.py
22	11	networkx/utils/misc.py

Date:   2015-04-09 01:38:33 +0200

    Improve shortest_simple_paths implementation and add more tests.
    
    I've removed the asserts, fixed the inability to use an arbitrary
    edge attribute as a weight, and speeded it up by computing
    separatetly the length/cost of the root and then adding it
    to the newly found partial path instead of computing the
    lenth/cost of the whole path when we push it to PathBuffer.

41	16	networkx/algorithms/simple_paths.py

commit 90d958897e3b29a33ebf352e55498e72a2959ace
Author: Jordi Torrents <jordi.t21@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-04-08 04:01:44 +0200

    Add shortest_simple_paths function.
    
    This function is based on Yen's algorithm for finding k shortest paths.
    It generates all simple paths between source and target starting from
    the shortest one. See #762 and #793 for prior work on this and discussion.
    
    This implementation is based on Andrey's work on #762. It generalizes his
    approach there to the weighted case, as in Greg's implementation posted
    on #793.
    
    Regarding the discussion on #762 about how to do the filtering of nodes
    and edges efficiently, this PR adds private modifications of the functions
    `bidirectional_shortest_path` and `bidirectional_dijkstra` (that accept
    containers with nodes and edges to exclude during the SP search) for its
    exclusive use.
    
    This still needs work, especially on documentation and tests. I'm pushing
    it so we can have the discussion with the code available.
    
    One thing to discuss is whether or not to include an one liner function
    to get the k shortest paths. Could be something like this:
    
    ```python
    from itertools import islice
    def k_shortest_paths(G, source, target, k, weight=None):
            return list(islice(nx.shortest_simple_paths(G, source, target, weight=weight), k))
    ```
    
    I think that, given that `all_simple_paths` is way faster in computing
    all paths, the principal use of `shortest_simple_paths` will be to get
    the k best/shortest paths. So it will be a more user friendly interface
    if we add it. However, we could also add this function as example in the
    `shortest_simple_paths` docstring. I'm ok either way. Thoughts?

473	2	networkx/algorithms/simple_paths.py
82	0	networkx/algorithms/tests/test_simple_paths.py

commit 504bd41c358b6fa4fa3271d91d23f73598d944e4
Merge: a3eca18b 79fd3441
Author: chebee7i <chebee7i@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-04-15 00:34:59 -0500

    Merge pull request #1437 from jfinkels/minors
    
    Adds function for computing a quotient graph.

commit 79fd344142dfce1e2f6c56669fb7c2f9a3446a3d
Author: Jeffrey Finkelstein <jeffrey.finkelstein@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-03-26 17:21:32 -0400

    Adds function for computing a quotient graph.
    
    The quotient graph of a graph `G` with respect to an equivalence
    relation `R` on the nodes of `G` is the graph whose vertex set is the
    equivalence classes `R` and where there is an edge joining class `c` to
    class `d` if some vertex in `c` is adjacent to some vertex in `d`.
    
    This commit places that function in a new module,
    `networkx/algorithms/minors.py`, for functions related to graph minors.

9	0	doc/source/reference/algorithms.minors.rst
1	0	doc/source/reference/algorithms.rst
1	0	doc/source/reference/credits.rst
1	0	networkx/algorithms/__init__.py
181	0	networkx/algorithms/minors.py
83	0	networkx/algorithms/tests/test_minors.py

commit 5c49eb2422f34498ada72a7521242c5a9173a04a
Author: Jordi Torrents <jordi.t21@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-03-14 23:10:16 +0100

    Add fast approximation for node connectivity.
    
    This PR adds White and Newman's fast approximation algorithm for
    finding node independent paths between two nodes. It finds them by
    computing their shortest path using BFS, marking the nodes of the path
    found as used and then searching other shortest paths excluding the
    nodes marked as used until no more paths exist. It is not exact because
    a shortest path could use nodes that, if the path were longer, may belong
    to two different node independent paths. Thus it only guarantees an
    strict lower bound on node connectivity.
    
    This implementation uses a modified version of `bidirectional_shortest_path`
    that accepts the extra parameter 'exclude', which is a container for nodes
    already used in other paths that should be ignored.

1	0	networkx/algorithms/approximation/__init__.py
405	0	networkx/algorithms/approximation/connectivity.py
158	0	networkx/algorithms/approximation/tests/test_connectivity.py

    Use a `for` loop instead of a `while` for iterating over antichains.
    
    This way we have 100% test coverage. The `break` statement in the
    while loop was never executed because we find the node cutset before
    ending the iteration over antichains of the condensation of the residual
    network.

commit 10ec6c319bcb4637774e2cd82b178177259dda92
Author: Jordi Torrents <jordi.t21@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-03-05 19:08:42 +0100

    Add all minimum-size k node cutsets algorithm.
    
    This PR implements Kanevsky's algorithm for all minimum-size separating
    node sets in an undirected graph as a generator of node sets.
    
    The most tricky thing about the implementation is that for reusing the
    residual network and the auxiliary graph for node connectivity (which
    is key for speed) we have to keep removing and adding edges to them
    instead of regenerating both each time we have to modify the input
    graph (the algorithm prescrives to add an edge each time we find
    a node cutset to avoid finding it again).
    
    This PR uses almost as is a function from SAGE (see `compute_antichains`),
    maybe we should ask permission to it's author to include it given that SAGE
    is GPL and we are BSD?

commit 3b241e97718fb782fd1b35ae42b372f61ba59f7c
Author: Jordi Torrents <jordi.t21@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-03-02 21:36:03 +0100

    Refactor complete_bipartite_graph. Fixes #1375.
    
    This commit reimplements `complete_bipartite_graph` using a generator
    expression instead of two nested for loops. Also adds the `bipartite`
    node attribute (that was missing, as per #1375).
    
    I've also moved the `complete_bipartite_graph` function from `classic.py`
    to `bipartite.py`. I think it's better to have all bipartite generators
    together.
    
    The function `complete_bipartite_graph` is used by other functions, such as
    `wheel_graph`, which was abusing the interface by passing -1 as the second
    argument of `complete_bipartite_graph` (for `wheel_graph(0)`) and hoping to
    get an empty graph with zero nodes. This is also fixed.

commit c6b2816115585f86a75bd60470220615ccc05e03
