commit 58a883cbd22c6f2944d7a00fd9236cbc0c7c7cad
Author: Ryan Nelson <rnelsonchem@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-01-23 23:20:08 -0500

    Iterate over DataFrame.values, fix doc example
    
    This improves performance substantially. DataFrame.iterrows incurs a large
    overhead as it creates a new Series for each row. Modified this function to
    loop over DataFrame.values instead, which is much more efficient. Each row is
    now returned as as Numpy array, so we have to use index matching instead.
    
    Fixed a couple of doc string examples as well that were causing problems in
    the doc build.

25	27	networkx/convert_matrix.py

commit afc7f06b91cbf1313582cd577eb195aa04357c0c
Author: Jeffrey Finkelstein <jeffrey.finkelstein@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-01-20 21:30:36 -0500

    Allows explicit conversion with parallel edges
    
    Adds the `parallel_edges` keyword argument to the `from_numpy_matrix`
    and `from_scipy_sparse_matrix`. This allows the user to specify whether
    to interpret an integer matrix as parallel edges in a multigraph or
    single weighted edges in a multigraph.
    
    This restores the default behavior of these functions that was changed
    by pull request #1305.

    Remove randomness from test_petersen to avoid fails

3	3	networkx/algorithms/tests/test_boundary.py

commit bbd42197b0c9342cc46658035e8055a08766f34c
Author: Dan Schult <dschult@colgate.edu>
Date:   2015-01-17 21:42:00 -0500

    Expand data keyword in G.edges and add default data
    
    When data=True, the whole data dictionary is returned for each edge.
    When data=False, no data is returned.
    Otherwise data is used as the attribute name of the edge data to return.
    >>> [ (u,v,edata['weight']) for u,v,edata in G.edges(data=True) ]
    becomes
    >>> G.edges(data='weight')
    
    >>> for n,nbrs in G.adjacency_iter():
    ...     for nbr,ddict in nbrs.items():
    ...         print (n,nbr,ddict.get('weight',1))
    becomes
    >>> G.edges(data='weight', default=1)

commit dd73a65e25b50943799f25aaf4f881de03af539b
Author: Jeffrey Finkelstein <jeffrey.finkelstein@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-01-03 21:59:20 -0500

    Maximum cardinality matching in bipartite graphs.
    
    Adds the Hopcroft--Karp algorithm for finding a maximum cardinality
    matching in bipartite graphs. Also adds an alternate implementation due
    to David Eppstein. Finally, adds a function that converts a maximum
    matching in a bipartite graph to a minimum vertex cover.
    
    Fixes issue #1303.

commit 9ba8d905e03ed604c786fdc195a7ac29b0664290
Merge: 616b4f7c f29fd478
Author: Aric Hagberg <aric.hagberg+github@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-01-12 14:16:34 -0700

    Merge pull request #1310 from jfinkels/symmetric_scipy
    
    Don't add edges twice when converting from numpy or scipy

commit f29fd4789f3e43012c4d76185d5df589d9af9240
Author: Jeffrey Finkelstein <jeffrey.finkelstein@gmail.com>
Date:   2014-12-18 12:47:36 -0500

    Don't add edges twice when converting from numpy
    
    Previously in `from_scipy_sparse_matrix()` and `from_numpy_matrix()`, if
    `create_using` were an undirected multigraph and the input matrix were
    symmetric, the edge (u, v) and the edge (v, u) would be added
    separately, thereby resulting in two parallel edges. This change makes
    the function behave more intelligently: it now assumes that when the
    input matrix is symmetric and `create_using` is undirected, the edge (u,
    v) should be added only once.

105	58	networkx/convert_matrix.py
11	0	networkx/tests/test_convert_numpy.py

commit cf6d0e3b650b5b43980b9fb608c5216756b0ea98
Author: Dan Schult <dschult@colgate.edu>
Date:   2015-01-01 19:20:53 -0500

    Better proposed structure for OrderedGraph and co.
    
    This supercedes #1268 as a proposed structure for OrderedGraph and
    ThinGraph class structures. It is based on discussion from #980 and
    has also been discussed in #1181, #1244, #1267, #1267
    
    This implementation includes examples (in docs and in tests) for 1)
    ordered nodes, 2) ordered nodes and edges and 3) thin (low RAM) graphs
    that don't need edge attributes [not related to ordered nodes].
    
    In this proposal, the dict-like arguments are assigned in a new class
    structure rather than assigning them to an instance of the SpecialGraph
    class. Something similar to:
    
    class OrderedGraph(SpecialGraph):
        node_dict_factory=OrderedDict
    G=OrderedGraph()
    
    If all goes well with this version (including reasonable speed)
    it might be reasonable to include it in the base classes Graph, etc.
    I think @ysitu prefers a more flexible base class than adding yet
    more graph classes, and all else equal (or almost equal) I agree.
    
    This pull request may be useful for people who wish OrderedGraph
    or ThinGraph and don't want to wait for 2.0

2	0	networkx/classes/__init__.py
1705	0	networkx/classes/special.py
121	0	networkx/classes/tests/test_special.py

commit b672ee5163515202bc438490f6712a1dcabb0b94
Author: Jeffrey Finkelstein <jeffrey.finkelstein@gmail.com>
Date:   2014-12-15 12:32:26 -0500

    Allows parallel edges when converting from numpy.
    
    Forces from_numpy_matrix() and from_scipy_sparse_matrix() to create a
    multigraph with parallel edges if the input adjacency matrix has integer
    entries and the `create_using` keyword argument is an instance of
    `MultiGraph`. In this case, each positive integer entry in the adjacency
    matrix is interpreted as the number of parallel edges, each with weight
    1, joining two vertices. Otherwise, if any of these conditions is not
    met, the function behaves as it previously did: an integer entry is
    interpreted as the weight of a single edge joining the two vertices.
    
    This is not a backwards compatible change: it changes the behavior of
    the function if the input is an integer matrix and `create_using` is a
    multigraph.

76	7	networkx/convert_matrix.py
24	0	networkx/tests/test_convert_numpy.py
25	0	networkx/tests/test_convert_scipy.py

    Adds a generator for the chordal p-cycle graph.
    
    Adds the chordal p-cycle graph, a mildly explicit algebraic construction
    of a family of 3-regular expander graphs. Also, moves both the existing
    expander graph generator function (for the Margulis-Gabber-Galil
    expander) and the new chordal cycle graph function to a new module,
    networkx.generators.expanders.

commit 6f1543afefbd66ebd11b8df8e1fbf3d6276cce4a
Merge: 4893ea6c 1e9c0be7
Author: chebee7i <chebee7i@gmail.com>
Date:   2014-10-31 18:44:14 -0500

    Merge pull request #1278 from johnyf/reinplace_selfloops
    
    bugfix: reinplace self-loop node with 0 fails

commit 1e9c0be732da846d9479e463da2a3c1c81bc0e25
Author: Ioannis Filippidis <jfilippidis@gmail.com>
Date:   2014-10-31 13:18:29 -0700

    bugfix: use ternary operator to replace node with self-loop in-place
    
    because otherwise `old == target and new` with old equal to target will evaluate to new. If new is 0 (a valid integer node), then the conjunction evaluates to False, masking that old is equal to target. The ternary operator implements the selection and avoids this issue.

4	4	networkx/relabel.py

commit 39813b032a19be74aad181485b393d30f88d426b
Author: Ioannis Filippidis <jfilippidis@gmail.com>
Date:   2014-10-31 13:16:55 -0700

    add test for in-place replacement of self-loop node with node 0

3	0	networkx/tests/test_relabel.py

Author: ysitu <ysitu@users.noreply.github.com>
Date:   2014-07-06 13:21:55 -0400

    Work around IronPython issue with compile()
    
    IronPython does not recognize __future__.CO_FUTURE_PRINT_FUNCTION passed
    as flags to compile(). Doctests automatically pass this flag when
    print_function is imported from __future__.

commit c306fb3a92b792133dee7f84be22a8b11a8c88d4
Author: ysitu <ysitu@users.noreply.github.com>
Date:   2014-05-31 00:49:08 -0400

    Handle unorderable nodes in functions using heapq
    
    Dijkstra implementations in networkx.algorithms.centrality.betweenness
    and networkx.algorithms.shortest_paths.weighted are affected. The Prim
    implementation in networkx.algorithms.mst is also affected.
    
    Although the A* implementation in astar.py already handles unorderable
    nodes, it is also modified to avoid expensive hashing for tie breaking.

commit 79e2e7a641a0143d1d9e913c7ec50cef81443cc3

2	8	networkx/algorithms/connectivity/utils.py

commit 4c483c98037d08b9aa82ea7d8c477271445acb44
Author: Jordi Torrents <jordi.t21@gmail.com>
Date:   2014-05-14 13:26:23 +0200

    Do not allow weighted computations in minimum_st_edge_cut.
    
    All connectivity and cut algorithms are supposed to work on unit
    capacity networks. minimum_st_edge_cut was the only exception, because
    it uses the new interface to flow algorithms, is potentially able to compute
    weighted cutsets. However, this complicated the implementation and could
    result in a NetworkXUnbounded exception if an user used as argument a
    graph with some but not all edges with an attribute called capacity. Since
    minimum_cut computes weighted cuts, there is no need to duplicate
    functionality here.

66	48	networkx/algorithms/connectivity/cuts.py
1	1	networkx/algorithms/connectivity/tests/test_cuts.py

    Improve cutoff handling: node connectivity is bounded by minimum degree.
    
    This change imporves significantly the speed of node_connectivity in
    denser graphs. For very sparse ones increases speed by ~5%.

commit 7cb64b682355912c02ecc550e4cd3b1c119cd4ac

    With the addition of the example of how to compute local node connectivity
    among all pairs of nodes reusing the data structures (added in the previous
    commit in the docstrings of local_node_connectivity). We can remove this
    function (which is the only one that has numpy dependency in the
    connectivity package).

commit c6b6233e3bf7d08d1e3ee1f0f5868104538089eb
Author: Jordi Torrents <jordi.t21@gmail.com>
Date:   2014-05-03 18:00:41 +0200

    Added examples reusing data structures and improved docstrings.

95	71	networkx/algorithms/connectivity/connectivity.py

commit 4690f1fba924e9e72295d6b6f8fe4e5ffa6650c1
Author: Jordi Torrents <jordi.t21@gmail.com>
Date:   2014-05-02 19:18:30 +0200

    Improve auxiliary digraphs for connectivity functions.
    
    1. The node mapping needed for node connectivity and minimum node cuts
    is now a graph attribute of the auxiliary digraph. Thus there is no
    need for a mapping parameter in the local version of these functions.
    
    2. Change the parameter name for the auxuliary digraph from `aux_digraph`
    to `auxiliary`. Also be consistent on the auxiliary digraph variable name
    in the code. Now it is always `H`.
    
    3. Added small sanity check for the auxiliary digraph for node connectivity.
    If a digraph is passed as a paramater for reuse, check that it has a graph
    attribute with the node mapping. If not we raise instead of rebuild the
    auxiliary digraph.

31	30	networkx/algorithms/connectivity/connectivity.py
19	16	networkx/algorithms/connectivity/cuts.py
5	0	networkx/algorithms/connectivity/tests/test_connectivity.py
5	0	networkx/algorithms/connectivity/tests/test_cuts.py
22	18	networkx/algorithms/connectivity/utils.py

commit 58257471a150706eb51cd6c734122300924d3234
Author: Jordi Torrents <jordi.t21@gmail.com>
Date:   2014-04-29 13:12:57 +0200

    Refactor connectivity package.
    
    Use the new algorithms and the new interfaces provided by the flow package.
    The code is quite clearer, and the new algorithms and interface provide
    a significant speed up in running time. For some problems, this code is one order
    of magnitude faster (see #1102 for bechmarks). So far the code is still
    backwards compatible, but we should discuss some possible non backward
    compatible improvements.

commit ddc453a057eae3909b370be47287e983a36a7d36
Author: Jordi Torrents <jordi.t21@gmail.com>
Date:   2014-04-26 21:41:19 +0200

    Do not require source and sink to build a residual network.
    
    Since the residual network is the same for every pair of nodes, delegate
    sanity checks on source and sink to algorithm implementations. This makes
    build_residual_network easier to use in the connectivity package, and in
    general.

commit 0335eba0d9ee81ee48c765a439be5c1a77153718
Author: Jordi Torrents <jordi.t21@gmail.com>
Date:   2014-04-24 18:57:08 +0200

    Improve interface to flow algorithms.
    
    This commit introduces backwards incompatible changes to the interface
    of flow algorithms:
    
    1. Split maximum_flow into maximum_flow (returns a tuple flow_value, flow_dict)
    and maximum_flow_value (returns only the value).
    
    2. Split minimum_cut into minimum_cut (returns a tuple cut_value, partition)
    and minimum_cut_value (returns only the value).
    
    3. Remove the short versions max_flow and min_cut.
    
    4. Remove flord_fulkerson_flow and ford_fulkerson_and_auxiliary
    
    5. Remove the parameter `legacy` from ford_fulkerson. It now returns a
    residual network as all other flow algorithms. I also tried to remove it
    but doing so requires quite a few changes in mincost.py because the code,
    tests, and the docstrings still relay on the its obsolete convention
    for flow_dict.

2	2	doc/source/reference/algorithms.flow.rst
1	1	networkx/algorithms/flow/edmonds_karp.py
18	197	networkx/algorithms/flow/ford_fulkerson.py
306	51	networkx/algorithms/flow/maxflow.py
1	1	networkx/algorithms/flow/preflow_push.py
1	1	networkx/algorithms/flow/shortest_augmenting_path.py
10	15	networkx/algorithms/flow/tests/test_maxflow.py
0	2	networkx/algorithms/flow/tests/test_maxflow_large_graph.py

commit 637035f27890ace6d10da058559e964af8437077

    Kwargs sanity check for maximum_flow and minimum_cut.
    
    Check that kwargs is empty if flow_func is None, if not raise NetworkXError. This way users will nor rely on the default_flow_func.

commit f8078713e977c116848164ac749bd533520baf3d
Author: Jordi Torrents <jordi.t21@gmail.com>
Date:   2014-04-18 14:42:11 +0200

    Keep refactoring. Implementation of ysitu's proposal in #1102.
    
    This implements most of ysitu's proposal (see #1102) on the inetrfaces of flow algorithms. It is still backwards compatible. The main changes are:
    
    1. Removed all {residual|value|flow} functions for the new algorithms. Each algorithm exposes only a function named `algorithm_name` that returns the residual network after computing the maximum flow. Internally we use residual networks everywhere. This simplifies code and tests.
    
    2. Added a new parameter `legacy` to `ford_fulkerson` (default True). If it's True it returns a tuple (flow_value, flow_dict) as it used to do. If `legacy` is False then it returns the residual network, with the flow_value and the flow_dict as graph attributes. Thus we can use it internally (tests, other functions) in more or less the same way that we use the new algorithms. Expanded docstrings explaining all this. The functions `ford_fulkerson_value` and `ford_fulkerson_residual` introduced in the first refactoring are removed. The functions `ford_fulkerson_flow` and `ford_fulkerson_flow_and_auxiliary` are kept here for backwards compatibility, but I'll remove them in a separated commit.
    
    3. I named the parameter `value_only` (ysitu proposed `min_cut_only`) and changed a bit the semantics. It defines what the functions `maximum_flow` and `minimum_cut` return. If True they return the maximum flow value, otherwise they return the actual flow or the set of edges that form the minimum cut. All algorithms recognize this parameter, for the ones in which it's not applicable they just ignore it.
    
    4. The `maximum_flow` and `minimum_cut` functions deal now with `ford_fulkerson` as especial case. They also accept `**kwargs` and pass them to the function implementing the computation. This still needs work and do some checks on the sanity of the arguments passed to flow algorothms.
    
    5. We import everything again from the flow package, without the {residual|value|flow} functions there is no need to keep stuff only to the flow package.
    
    6. I've just adapted the old tests, more tests needed for testing the interface and new features of maximum_flow and minimum_cut. Now tests take less time because we are not testing redundant {residual|value|flow} functions.
    
    7. `max_flow` and `min_cut` are alias for `maximum_flow` and `minimum_cut`. I think it's not a good idea to have them behave different, it could be a source of confusion.

10	11	doc/source/reference/algorithms.flow.rst

commit 08f36ea5bb83a8d2da18bfeeea9ba457954efe25
Author: Jordi Torrents <jordi.t21@gmail.com>
Date:   2014-04-12 22:31:30 +0200

    Refactor flow package.
    
    This refactoring follows from the discussion at #1096 and #1095. It is fully backwards compatible. The main changes are:
    
    1. Rename max_flow and min_cut to maximum_flow and minimum_cut to be consistent with NetworkX naming convention. The short names can still be used (eg nx.max_flow(...)) but are not in the documentation.
    
    2. maximum_flow and minimum_cut accept a new parameter flow_func for the function that will perform the computation. A default_flow_func is set, which is preflow_push_value, based on the benckmarks by @ysitu at #1099.
    
    3. The legacy implementation of ford_fulkerson and firends is separated in its own file and refactored for it to follow the new conventions in the function names, the implementation is the same.
    
    4. Added a new function that return the residual network for each algorithm implementation. Also added docstrings explaining the conventions used in the residual network.
    
    4. Refactored tests. Now it is easy to add a new maximum flow algorithm for testing. They take maybe a bit too long, but now we test all flow related functions.
    
    5. The functions <algo_name>_{value|flow|residual} are not imported to NetworkX base namespace, it is necessary now to explicitly import them from networkx.algorithms.flow, the exception is ford_fulkerson_flow for backwards compatibility.
    
    6. The maximum flow related functions imported in networkx namespace are: maximum_flow, minimum_cut, ford_fulkerson, preflow_push, shortest_augmenting_path. For convenience max_flow and min_cut are also imported. And for backwards compatibility: ford_fulkerson_flow and ford_fulkerson_flow_and_auxiliary.

    Return empty graph for random 0-regular graph
    
    There is exactly one 0-regular graph, namely the empty graph. A call to
    `random_regular_graph(0, n)` now returns the empty graph on n nodes instead of
    the null graph.

commit f501ab4119d4ee2d243e490c5b2cd6fe7491faca
Merge: ffea96a3 1174d86f
Author: Aric Hagberg <aric.hagberg@gmail.com>
Date:   2014-03-31 12:12:11 -0600

    Merge pull request #1089 from jfinkels/patch-1
    
    Inputs in bipartite generator funcs must be lists

commit 1174d86f24b705627b51a88877a376d365977c4d
Author: jfinkels <jfinkels@users.noreply.github.com>
Date:   2014-03-31 13:30:15 -0400

    Inputs in bipartite generator funcs must be lists
    
    The documentation states that the degree sequences provided as inputs to the
    `bipartite_configuration_model` function may be lists or "iterators". However,
    the code includes calls to `len()`, multiple iterations over the same iterable,
    and access of elements at specific indices, all of which fail for generator
    expressions.
    
    Changes the documentation in the functions in this module to be clearer about
    this requirement.

9	9	networkx/generators/bipartite.py

commit ffea96a37305bd9be5009f52b5ec6048a176c760
Merge: 5bfe221f b3c9a9ee

commit 7e00aebb139ef654a7f9e9ed09c751ff75cb70b8
Author: Eugenio Piasini <e.piasini@ucl.ac.uk>
Date:   2013-12-07 01:35:46 +0000

    Don't import Graph Atlas generator if the interpreter is Jython.
    
    The graph_atlas_g function is larger than the maximum method size
    limit in Java (64K). This is just a workaround to get networkx to work
    with Jython, and obviously it would be preferable to take all of the
    Graph Atlas data out of the body of the function, and save it to a
    separate data file.

commit efec7a6a880fa07c3932e8ffe9b4db2207159ad6
Merge: 52dd3e50 3e72b389
Author: Aric Hagberg <aric.hagberg@gmail.com>
Date:   2013-11-05 16:38:23 -0800

    Merge pull request #1001 from hagberg/stochastic-zero
    
    Stochastic zero row + pagerank
    
    The various pagerank(), pagerank_numpy(), and pagerank_scipy() should produce the same results now for cases with weighted graphs with zero row sums or negative weights.   The negative weight case may produce answers but I don't know if they are meaningful (certainly that breaks the intentions and assumptions of the algorithm.)  The convergence tolerances now match between implementations too.

    errors, then we wouldn't change directories. And then no tests
    would be run.

commit 66ea32416fddb1c3d34ed1f319afbf569e89eaa9
Author: Dan Schult <dschult@colgate.edu>
Date:   2013-07-11 14:23:57 -0400

    Format cycles from simple_cycles w/o last node
    
    Cycles in networkx are represented by a list of nodes.  But
    simple_cycles() repeated the last node of the cycle.  This removes
    that repetition to bring simple_cycles in line with other cycle
    routines.  Related discussion in #889, #890.
    
    Also corrected some doctests and updated tests for this change.

7	7	networkx/algorithms/cycles.py
14	14	networkx/algorithms/tests/test_cycles.py

commit 7701d23b3524aced690411c6dc7e49fba496394e
Author: Dan Schult <dschult@colgate.edu>
Date:   2013-07-11 11:54:20 -0400

    Slight speedup in simple_cycles.  Order differs from recursive now.
    
    Popping nodes from the end instead of beginning gives a different order,
    but still valid.  Cycles now are a cyclic permutation of those reported
    by recursive routine.  This revealed holes in tests that are fixed here.

commit a5cc85614d35522417a8b704592e081f6f761fae
Author: Andreas Amann <a.amann@ucc.ie>
Date:   2013-06-26 21:24:11 +0100

    Allow larger number of neighbors in watts_strogatz_graph and newman_watts_strogatz_graph
    
    previously the code
    
    import networkx as nx
    nx.watts_strogatz_graph(10,6,0.0)
    
    would give the following error:
    
    networkx.exception.NetworkXError: k>=n/2, choose smaller k or larger n
    
    However, it should yield a ring network, with every node attached to 6
    neighbors.
    
    In order to obtain this, we now also need to check that we only rewire
    an edge starting at a node, if the degree of that node is less than
    n-1.  This avoids an infinite loop in the rewiring algorithm.

8	8	networkx/generators/random_graphs.py

commit d38de1f4df8c50917fb2b82ea15e3f816d59e942
Author: Dan Schult <dschult@colgate.edu>
Date:   2013-06-17 17:17:51 -0400

    Create nonrecursive function for simple_cycles
    
    Copied simple_cycles to recursive_simple_cycles and added a new
    simple_cycles that is the same algorithm but not recursive.  Two
    changes in the API for simple_cycle are that
    1) it now returns a generator instead of returning a list.
    2) Cycles no longer repeat the first node as the last.  The last
    node in the list is assumed to connect to the first node on the list.
    
    Tests added to compare output of simple_cycles and recursive_simple_cycles
    
    Thanks to erikasantos and friedsoap for instigating this and suggesting
    helpful changes (which I incorporated).  This addresses #874 #888 #889

126	3	networkx/algorithms/cycles.py
19	10	networkx/algorithms/tests/test_cycles.py

commit a18f09972692b2473569f0c3a386e9fb53527e1a
Author: Aric Hagberg <aric.hagberg@gmail.com>
Date:   2013-03-16 21:50:28 -0600

    Don't copy subgraphs in cuthill_mckee_ordering().
    
    The connected_component_subgraphs() function used in the cuthill_mckee_ordering() makes a copy.  That causes new node objects to be created which might not be desirable when returning a node ordering if the hash changes when a new object is created. Fix by not copying nodes when forming a subgraph of connected nodes.

commit df3fe38052aeb82ab4ac533b922034329e824836
Author: Juan Nunez-Iglesias <jni@janelia.hhmi.org>
Date:   2012-11-27 23:44:20 +1100

    Refactor functions to use faster nx.shortest_path_length

9	15	networkx/algorithms/dag.py
0	4	networkx/algorithms/tests/test_dag.py

commit 443455460a6f749ee0603a382f9b0e0efde209bc
Author: Juan Nunez-Iglesias <jni@janelia.hhmi.org>
Date:   2012-11-22 15:28:06 +1100

    Improve performance of descendants and ancestors
    
    The `descendants` function for DAGs was slow because it performed a
    check of whether the input graph was a DAG. This is now off by default.
    
    In addition, the inverse function, `ancestors`, would previously
    reverse the entire graph to find ancestors using BFS. A modification
    to the `bfs_edges()` function allows reversing the BFS itself, avoiding
    the cost of the full graph reversal.

15	8	networkx/algorithms/dag.py
2	2	networkx/algorithms/tests/test_dag.py
9	5	networkx/algorithms/traversal/breadth_first_search.py

commit e4419f75cd29f09878fce459a2e74f3363f6b4d6
Author: Juan Nunez-Iglesias <jni@janelia.hhmi.org>
Date:   2012-11-14 21:34:38 +1100

    Make check for DAG optional in descendants algo
    
    When searching for descendants many times, it is cumbersome to check
    each time whether the graph is a DAG. Therefore, this check can now
    be disabled by a keyword argument.

2	2	networkx/algorithms/dag.py

commit dbd4b01eca060f896fbc6bb1b18d03727170acf2
Author: Juan Nunez-Iglesias <jni@janelia.hhmi.org>
Date:   2012-11-13 17:40:13 +1100

    Add ancestor and descendant functions for DAGs
    
    Ancestors are all nodes from which you can reach the source node.
    Descendants are all nodes reachable from the source node. Both are
    defined only in DAGs.

37	0	networkx/algorithms/dag.py

commit 9e5d8e1681c84b1dd9c52f7df73bdeee386e3634
Author: Alejandro Weinstein <alejandro.weinstein@gmail.com>
Date:   2012-07-21 08:36:54 -0600

    Fix normalized laplacian when the graph contains selfloops.
    
    When G contains selfloops, the normalized laplacian is defined as NL = D^{-1/2}
    (D - A) D^{-1/2}, with A the adjencency matrix and D a diagonal matrix with the
    sum of the rows of A in the diagonal. The current NetworkX implementation use D
    with the degree of the nodes in the diagonal, which count selfloops twice (this
    is the right convension in general, but not the correct one for computing the
    normalized laplacian).

34	34	networkx/linalg/laplacianmatrix.py

commit 899c3cb33a80c7dc5076f7ef3284dcc52d3d6c92

commit 5604f79068220836975f0ee65ab85ad7febb1751
Author: Dan Schult <dschult@colgate.edu>
Date:   2011-05-18 17:13:19 -0400

    Allow weight keyword argument in centrality measures and shortest_path routines.
    weight is None means don't use weights
    weight is True means use 'weight' edge data key (backward compatibility)
    otherwise weight is the edge data key to determine the edge weights.
    
    Addressess #509

commit 0a61b253f11ff4c137c4020e6e81d565f02219ac
Author: aric <none@none>
Date:   2010-04-16 00:21:20 +0000

    Add the weakly connected algorithms. Addresses #302
    In simple testing weakly_connected_components(D) is
    about an order of magnitude faster than
    connected_components(D.to_undirected()) and at least twice
    as fast as connected_components(Graph(D)).
    
    No tests are included.

    subgraphview()    This returns a read-only view on the subgraph

commit bce794cac9209b0023fa9c481cf15ff9adf7eb89
Author: aric <none@none>
Date:   2009-12-17 23:21:11 +0000

    Finesse name clash of write_dot() and read_dot().
    
    Both are provided by either pydot or pygraphviz.  Set
    pygraphviz.write_dot() and pygraphviz.read_dot() to be the default but
    don't stomp on pydot_write_dot() and pydot.read_dot() if pydot exists
    but pygraphviz doesn't.

      r813 | dschult | 2008-08-14 10:42:59 -0600 (Thu, 14 Aug 2008) | 11 lines
    
      Remove to_directed and to_undirected methods.
      I spent too much time comparing DiGraph(G) to G.to_directed()
      and even with lots of fiddling I couldn't get the methods
      to be faster than the from_whatever.
      As written, they are 2-3 times slower.
      We wanted to get rid of them anyway and it looks like convert is ready for that.
    
      I also adjusted LabeledGraph so that LabeledGraph(LG) copies the labels
      as well as the graph.

      Decided not to have it copy the name too...
      Too complicated and not sure that copying the name is the best/natural choice.

      r815 | dschult | 2008-08-14 12:36:55 -0600 (Thu, 14 Aug 2008) | 7 lines
    
      Changed the keyword for subgraph from copy=True to newgraph=True.
      It used to be inplace=False.  Copy has too many other meanings in this package.
      Not sure that newgraph is the best though either.  I'd prefer to take
      out the option of making a subgraph by deleting nodes.
      That's what delete_nodes_from is for.

      graphs using attribute 'adj' instead of 'add_node'.
      This will allow future e.g. scipy sparse matrix classes
      to use add_node without confusing from_whatever().
      We really use thing.adj and not thing.add_node anyway.

commit 28b215a7fe62bfcb1c2046d392734d89e02cc532
Author: dschult <none@none>
Date:   2007-10-16 19:33:48 +0000

    Speed up neighbors considerably by replacing
    return list(self.neighbors_iter(n))        with
    return self.adj[n].keys()      (with a try-except to catch errors)
    
    This doesn't work for xgraph because current API returns a
    neighbor twice if there are multiple edges.  So XGraph goes
    back to list(self.neighbor_iter(n)).
    
    I think this is actually an incorrect definition of neighbors!
    In neighbors, each neighbor should be listed once...
    But I'm not going to change it in the trunk.  Look to NEP for that.
    
    --HG--
    extra : convert_revision : svn%3A3ed01bd8-26fb-0310-9e4c-ca1a4053419f/networkx/trunk%40694

8	5	networkx/digraph.py
13	7	networkx/graph.py
19	3	networkx/xdigraph.py
14	1	networkx/xgraph.py

commit 62219d19bc755b2a1c0461b769d7dc9e5d33dd3f
Author: cellison <none@none>
Date:   2007-08-21 22:49:09 +0000

    Fixed a logic error during update of GMState.inout_x and DiGMState.in_x, and DiGMState.out_x.
    
    When updating GMState.inout_1 and GMState.inout_2, we need to check if a node already
    exists in the dictionary.  Otherwise, we will overwrite when the node was added to the
    dictionary---this screws up backtracking.
    
    Also, minor documentation changes.
    
    fixes #122
    
    (this is a recommit so that the changeset is linked to closing of the ticket)
    
    --HG--
    extra : convert_revision : svn%3A3ed01bd8-26fb-0310-9e4c-ca1a4053419f/networkx/trunk%40680

0	1	networkx/isomorphvf2.py

    Fixed a logic error during update of GMState.inout_x and DiGMState.in_x, and DiGMState.out_x.
    
    When updating GMState.inout_1 and GMState.inout_2, we need to check if a node already
    exists in the dictionary.  Otherwise, we will overwrite when the node was added to the
    dictionary---this screws up backtracking.

commit b1dbdd24bcd8b2b42ed9067df01bf29d3a0c6f17
Author: dschult <none@none>
Date:   2007-06-20 04:37:25 +0000

    Fixes #116
    
    Change convert.from_dict_of_dicts so that it creates valid
    networkx graphs when the dict_of_dicts is incomplete: that is
    when the dict_of_dicts shows only one direction of an undirected edge.
    This change also makes sure G.pred is updated for DiGraphs.

commit b2c16fca85e15725959fd06a7708dbbdd2d7d18f
Author: dschult <none@none>
Date:   2007-02-20 22:07:30 +0000

    Add a predecessor routine for weighted networks called:
    dijkstra_predecessor_and_distance() to path.py.
    and put a hook in betweenness_centrality so that if you
    use the argument     weighted_edges=True
    betweenness is calculated using dijkstra shortest paths.
    
    Also, removed many default arguments which were set to False
    and then tested.  When the argument is set to 0 (a node name)
    the code treated it as False (b/c False is 0).
    So, I changed them to None and tested for None.
    
    Added some tests to path and centrality modules but could use more.

commit 471f7529a31b679e6ac779c70a267adcb80c3991
Author: dschult <none@none>
Date:   2007-02-15 20:07:26 +0000

    Attempt to address multiedge difficulties in convert.py using from_dict_of_dicts:
    - changed from_dict_of_dict to operate on G.dj directly instead of through add_edge()
         This allows multiedges to be converted without too much hassle.
    
    While in there, I also:
    - centralized the preparation of create_using to a routine convert.prep_create_using()
    - changed some docstrings and removed ==True in if statements.
    - put in warning comments that looking for "multiedge" attributes isn't very good for
      finding out if there is edge_data.  Somenoe could make weightedgraph without multiedges
      and it wouldn't work for that case.  Still thinking about how to test for edge_data...
    - replace try/except with if for from_scipy_spase_matrix

commit 015c7814f37afd6f182e33c62fbec6653dce8619
Author: dschult <none@none>
Date:   2007-01-11 20:11:07 +0000

    Change/remove **kwds in many routines where not needed.
    Found bug in tests for operators related to kwds.
    
    cliques.py: convert to standard create_using= usage only keyword needed is name so put it in.
    operators.py:  again, name is the only keyword so declare it specifically.
    utils.py:   many potentially buggy uses of kwds which I probably put in long ago. easy replace.
    hybrid.py:  replace **kwds with actual keyword arguments.
    tests/operators.txt    one call still used result= instead of create_using= but kwds hides those
       kinds of errors.
    
    These were the easy ones to fix.
    Other modules include search_class.py and tree.py which I couldn't see if there
    would be a bigger impact, so left them alone.
    In drawing/nx_pydot.py  could probably get rid of the 3 **kwds in there
    but I can't test it so I didn't change anything.
    
    --HG--

    - added hold=None to args of draw() instead of in kwds
    - removed with_labels= in routines where not used (gets sent through via kwds)

    - removed all imports from within functions--not needed anyway...functions already imported at top.

      hold from namespace so we can use it as a function argument.

commit 51baa8f97d0203dd3b5bc6659b35988c0fd2952d
Author: dschult <none@none>
Date:   2006-12-12 21:34:48 +0000

    Remove **kwds from __init__ on graph classes.
    We don't need it and it causes bugs (our tests for selfloops
    used the keyword loops=True and it wasn't caught).
    
    Also cleaned up the __init__ methods defaults for name
    and removed the self=   portion of self=convert.from_whatever()
    because create_using does the work and self= creates a local
    variable named 'self' that HAPPENS to point to the same structure as
    the argument variable 'self' and I thought that was prone to
    becoming buggy someday.
    
    Added tests to check data= and name= for each of the four classes.
    
    --HG--
    extra : convert_revision : svn%3A3ed01bd8-26fb-0310-9e4c-ca1a4053419f/networkx/trunk%40496

commit 36e7648019e467aca6a12c454cf7806acb105b56
Author: dschult <none@none>
Date:   2006-11-18 06:41:09 +0000

    Changed code for degree method (and friends in_degree/out_degree)
    so that they call degree_iter and friends.  This allows the new
    result that the order of the degree values sent back in a list is
    the same as the order of the nodes in nbunch.  see ticket 75.
    
    Added tests using a simple 3-node case when the order is not the
    same using dict.values().
    
    This is not finished work however because XDiGraph doesn't have
    degree_iter (and iter friends).  I think that means that XDiGraph's
    degree_iter has been broken all along.  That was more than I wanted
    to mess with tonight.

commit 90476f8aa6fe604cd373a648c9cc9fbdf9f83720
Author: aric <none@none>

    spurious "weighted" keyword in adj_matrix

commit fa7c73d0de8e1c8c229f645ddff90f9e3682ceda
Author: aric <none@none>
Date:   2006-11-10 17:02:04 +0000

    Remove weight_matrix in favor of plain adj_matrix
    
    I am following when I can Sedgewick's book on graph algorithms
    that adjacency matrix is for both weighted and unweighted graphs.
    
    Using numpy it is very easy to make a 0|1 adjacency matrix out of
    a 1|weight adjacency matrix e.g.
    
    >>> A=adj_matrix(X) # X is a weighted XGraph
    
    >>> B=numpy.where(A,0,1)
    
    --HG--
    extra : convert_revision : svn%3A3ed01bd8-26fb-0310-9e4c-ca1a4053419f/networkx/trunk%40448

2	2	networkx/convert.py
0	14	networkx/spectrum.py

commit 02299af1a886d3eac6b17fe52313eaf79266418a
Author: aric <none@none>
Date:   2006-11-10 16:33:53 +0000

    remove add_edges
    
    Some reasons for removing:
    
     - I think there could be confusion between add_edge and add_edges
       if we keep it.
    
     - >>> for v in nodelist:
               G.add_edge(u,v)
       is pretty simple to write
    
    Some reasons against:
    
     - G.add_edges_from(zip([u]*len(nodelist),nodelist))
       is not that simple to write
    
    --HG--
    extra : convert_revision : svn%3A3ed01bd8-26fb-0310-9e4c-ca1a4053419f/networkx/trunk%40445

0	13	networkx/base.py

    M    networkx/drawing/nx_pygraphviz.py
    Attempt to copy properties to and from graphviz dot data and
    NetworkX objects. The data is stored in auxiliary dictionaries.
    If XGraph or XDiGraph are used and the edge data is a dictionary,
    then the edge data will be used as edge attributes for dot data.

    objects.

    Add converters of various formats to/from NetworkX graph types.

            - dict of dicts

            - scipy sparse matrix types

    with argument that is one of the known formats that can be converted
    e.g. if A is a numpy matrix

commit 86d9c77fb39784d7ab12d1532602c8de8ad9cdf3
Author: aric <none@none>
Date:   2006-06-11 23:51:39 +0000

    Fixes #37.
    
    Passing a digraph to a connected component function now
    raises an exception.  This applies the terminology decsion that the
    term "connected" should be only be used for digraphs.
    
    This solution may not be the final answer on implementation
    but should prevent some confusion for now.
    
    It might be useful to implement reachability and strong connectiviy
    for digraphs.

commit 4d5506034ad250f9dc2d81c614aac18f847a526c
Author: dschult <none@none>
Date:   2006-06-09 19:10:23 +0000

    Change edges_iter and friends to raise an exception if
    argument nbunch is neither a node nor iterable.
    
    This doesn't cover the case of non-node strings because
    strings are iterable--so string nbunch's will return an
    empty list if they are not a node in the graph and none of
    their letters is either.

commit 072e6ef6e6ad8bf3585f17dfb626d5626524adb7
Author: aric <none@none>
Date:   2006-06-02 20:48:01 +0000

    Fixes #45.
    Add asarray wrappers to data from layout positions.
    Ensures nx_pylab will consistently use the array package
    specified by the matplotlib configuration.
    
    The problem was:
    The functions in layout.py will try to use numpy first.
    Ff the user chooses Numeric as a backend for matplotlib then
    the resulting function of nx_pylab.py was upredictable since
    there was a mix of Numeric and numpy arrays.
    
    --HG--
    extra : convert_revision : svn%3A3ed01bd8-26fb-0310-9e4c-ca1a4053419f/networkx/trunk%40283

17	17	networkx/drawing/nx_pylab.py

commit 6d905e7e66d8fb68a901e610cb0fd9dfa4875392
Author: dschult <none@none>
Date:   2006-05-25 20:38:49 +0000

    Add a method to process nbunch.  This could be used within
    base.py at the cost of a (local) function lookup and benefit
    of more readable code.  +1 from me, but won't do unless others
    agree.
    
    Outside base.py and xbase.py, one can use this method
    G.prepare_nbunch(nbunch)   to process the nbunch: make it
    a list of nodes in nbunch which are also in G.
    When we leave python 2.3 we can make this return an iterator
    if desired.
    
    I implemented this feature in clustering() and triangles().
    
    tests for clustering all had answers of 0.0 or 1.0, so I added a twist.
    
    --HG--
    extra : convert_revision : svn%3A3ed01bd8-26fb-0310-9e4c-ca1a4053419f/networkx/trunk%40274

70	49	networkx/base.py

commit 02cc6bf21bb389bef1c6dfe7aa9c057dd772e386
Author: dschult <none@none>
Date:   2006-04-01 15:16:11 +0000

    Attempt to allow numpy or Numeric.
    This is crude in that if numpy isn't available it
    just import Numeric with the name numpy.  Some things
    presumably wouldn't work this way--but we don't use
    those things.  Our usage of Numeric/numpy is pretty
    simplistic.
    
    I tested it on versions of python with both Numeric/numpy,
    with only numpy, only Numeric and without either.  It seems
    to work fine.  Any suggestions on further tests and I'll
    try them too.
    
    --HG--
    extra : convert_revision : svn%3A3ed01bd8-26fb-0310-9e4c-ca1a4053419f/networkx/trunk%40220

2	2	networkx/__init__.py
13	11	networkx/spectrum.py

commit a1a9551e4dfccb793688677170a57cb6e99630b6
Author: dschult <none@none>
Date:   2006-03-14 18:55:45 +0000

    Change the unnormalized betweenness_centrality to match that
    defined in the cited Brandes paper.   There are lots of ways
    to define this, but since there are no comments about it, I
    thought it better to use the one from the paper.
    The difference is an off-by-one for each node,
    essentially starting at 0 instead of 1.
    Now it starts at 0.
    
    I moved the normalization outside the inner loop where
    appropriate.
    
    I also added some tests for the unnormalized option.
    
    --HG--
    extra : convert_revision : svn%3A3ed01bd8-26fb-0310-9e4c-ca1a4053419f/networkx/trunk%40205

15	9	networkx/centrality.py
28	0	networkx/tests/centrality.txt

    code used for the threshold paper draft to networkx.

    manner used by networkx for betweenness_centrality.

commit e681e6191bb3590a619e727e065fba9ac85ff13c
Author: aric <none@none>
Date:   2006-03-03 03:25:59 +0000

    Add predecessor function.
    
    def predecessor(G,source,target=False,cutoff=False):
    
    Returns dictionary of predecessors for the path from source to all nodes in G.
    
    Optional target returns only predecessors between source and target.
    Cutoff is a limit on the number of hops traversed.
    
    Example for the path graph 0-1-2-3
    
    >>> G=path_graph(4)
    >>> print G.nodes()
    [0, 1, 2, 3]
    >>> predecessor(G,0)
    {0: [], 1: [0], 2: [1], 3: [2]}
    
    Fixes #26.
    
    The code to build a shortest path from a predecessor dictionary
    is left as an exercise.
    
    --HG--
    extra : convert_revision : svn%3A3ed01bd8-26fb-0310-9e4c-ca1a4053419f/networkx/trunk%40171

41	0	networkx/paths.py
11	1	networkx/tests/paths.txt

commit efe5ef29e83018226f062b66edd8afacc9d90275
Author: swart <none@none>
Date:   2006-02-18 13:07:39 +0000

    added extra switch to ordering
    option in convert_node_labels_to_integers
    
    can now be called as
    GG=convert_node_labels_to_integers(G,ordering='sorted')
    
    and the node ordering in GG will be that produced
    by sorted(G.nodes())
    
    Note that this can be expensive for large graphs
    as it will have to generate a full list of all nodes
    in memory
    
    --HG--
    extra : convert_revision : svn%3A3ed01bd8-26fb-0310-9e4c-ca1a4053419f/networkx/trunk%40167

commit d7ca8e42c1cd6436a3131e28b6e156bafe353a72
Author: aric <none@none>
Date:   2006-01-29 20:11:19 +0000

    Substantial changes related to digraphs and definitions of neighbors()
    and edges() that could break exisiting code.
    
    neighbors(), successors(), and predecessors() using with_labels now
    returns a list of pairs (u,v).  If you want a dictionary (the previous
    behavior) you can use dict(neighbors(n,with_labels=True))
    
    For DiGraphs:
    
    The current definition of edges is edges=out_edges
    The current definition of neighbors is out_neighbors
    These are simple to modify if there is a compelling reason.
    
    edges(nbunch=None)code=out_edges(nbunch=None) - all edges pointing out of nbunch
    in_edges(nbunch=None) - all edges pointing in to nbunch
    
    neighbors(nbunch=None,with_labels=False)=successors=out_neighbors
        reformatted version of out_edges
    
    predecessors(nbunch=None,with_labels=False)=in_neighbors
       reformatted version of in_edges
    
    I think in_degree and out_degree can be simplified in terms of these functions.
    
    Code review and testing welcome.
    
    --HG--
    extra : convert_revision : svn%3A3ed01bd8-26fb-0310-9e4c-ca1a4053419f/networkx/trunk%40146

102	70	networkx/base.py
18	16	networkx/tests/base_DiGraph.txt
3	3	networkx/tests/base_Graph.txt
5	5	networkx/tests/xbase_DiGraph.txt
6	4	networkx/tests/xbase_Graph.txt
11	12	networkx/tests/xbase_PseudoGraph.txt
146	134	networkx/xbase.py

commit a48afc41b9af691900f95221ac381efeebadff00
Author: aric <none@none>

commit afed3b300273c7979886fa329ff07bf0d5e74d36
Author: aric <none@none>
Date:   2005-12-16 02:08:11 +0000

    A slightly modified approach to using None for edge data
    
    Added the method delete_multiedges(u,v) that will delete all edges
    between u and v (XGraph/XDiGraph)
    
    XGraph()
    delete_edge(u,v) will delete the edge (u,v,d) if multiedges=False
    (same behavior as Graph/DiGraph)
    
    You still must specify the data d in (u,v,d) to delete_edge if
    multiedges=False or no edge will be deleted.
    
    --HG--
    extra : convert_revision : svn%3A3ed01bd8-26fb-0310-9e4c-ca1a4053419f/networkx/trunk%40113

17	16	networkx/base.py
6	6	networkx/tests/base_DiGraph.txt
3	3	networkx/tests/base_Graph.txt
26	26	networkx/tests/xbase_DiGraph.txt
22	22	networkx/tests/xbase_Graph.txt
69	54	networkx/tests/xbase_PseudoGraph.txt
130	136	networkx/xbase.py

commit c379a367dd8cac729c8cd0ce4ae772c685f86abe
Author: aric <none@none>
Date:   2005-12-01 18:41:23 +0000

    update testing infrastructure
    
    now you can test in three different ways
    1) from base package directory:
       python setup.py test
       will test the whole package
    2) from source direcotry:
       python code.py
       will test the single file code.py
    3) from test directory:
       python test.py
       will test the whole package
    
    The technique in test.py to find the test directory feels like a hack:
    testdir=networkx.__path__[0]+os.sep+"tests"
    
    test_all.py
    test_single.py
    are obsoleted by this change
    
    full testing of the drawing and generators is not implemented yet
    but those routines can be tested individualy for now
    
    --HG--
    extra : convert_revision : svn%3A3ed01bd8-26fb-0310-9e4c-ca1a4053419f/networkx/trunk%4093

2	0	networkx/tests/__init__.py
8	8	networkx/tests/test.py
0	83	networkx/tests/test_all.py
0	46	networkx/tests/test_single.py

commit 6f3f9e6ece3179213d4b1170c4b90b4a84a6bc17
Author: dschult <none@none>
Date:   2005-10-21 16:01:20 +0000

    This is in response to trac report # 19 which suggests a speedup for dijkstra().
    
    The suggestion is to check for duplicates on the priority queue before
    adding a node.  I chose to have the algorithm check when removing
    rather than when adding to the queue (more simple implementation).
    This probably requires a bigger queue than checking while adding, but
    it seems faster than searching the queue each time a node is added.
    (? though maybe an efficient non-dup priority queue algorithm exists ?)
    
    This fix at least removes the need to check for neighbors multiple times.
    So it realizes the bulk of the speedup hinted at by trac # 19.
    
    --HG--
    extra : convert_revision : svn%3A3ed01bd8-26fb-0310-9e4c-ca1a4053419f/networkx/trunk%4067

1	0	networkx/paths.py

commit 24d214bae216169e8e67e7fd0eaaf36fd8db66af
Author: dschult <none@none>
Date:   2005-10-06 18:41:39 +0000

    When I flattened the queue, I didn't check for duplicates
    so top_sort listed same nodes more than once sometimes.
    This change fixes that issue and adds some tests.
    
    --HG--
    extra : convert_revision : svn%3A3ed01bd8-26fb-0310-9e4c-ca1a4053419f/networkx/trunk%4066

3	0	networkx/paths.py
10	0	tests/paths.txt

commit 81c164d9f6d1637208d55020eadc68d1f0482493
Author: dschult <none@none>
Date:   2005-10-06 03:52:27 +0000

    The code for topo sort is much cleaner now and easier to read
    at the expense of agreeing with its recursive partner.  The two
    algorithms read the successors list in opposite directions now
    (which let me flatten an ugly list of lists).  Since successors'
    order is arbitrary, both algorithms give correct sorts, but now
    disagree (topo sort is not unique).
    
    If we want them to agree, I could add a .reverse()
    
    Perhaps their disagreement could be a feature if someone wants two
    topo sorts for some reason.
    
    --HG--
    extra : convert_revision : svn%3A3ed01bd8-26fb-0310-9e4c-ca1a4053419f/networkx/trunk%4064

17	25	networkx/paths.py
1	1	tests/paths.txt
